{{notability|Sport|date=April 2016}} {{refimprove|date=April 2016}} The '''1976 Rhodesian Grand Prix''' was held at Donnybrook Raceway in [[Harare|Salisbury]], [[Rhodesia]] on the 31 July 1976. It was a non-championship round of the South African [[Formula Atlantic]] series. It was won by Roy Klomfass driving a British-built Ralt RT1. ==Results== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! Pos !! No. !! Driver !! Constructor !! Sponsor !! Laps |- ! 1 | 5 | Roy Klomfass | [[Ralt]] - [[Ford]] | Team Gunston | 40 |- ! 2 | 3 | Nols Nieman | Wheatcroft - [[Ford]] | [[Benson & Hedges]] /Alex Blignault | 40 |- ! 3 | 1 | Dave Charlton | Modus - [[Ford]] | [[Lucky Strike]] | 40 |- ! 4 | ? | John Gibb | [[Chevron Cars Ltd|Chevron]] - [[Ford]] | Mum for Men/Pioneer Hi Fi | ? |- ! 5 | ? | John Amm | [[Brabham]] - [[Ford]] | ? | ? |- ! 6 | 2 | Tony Martin | [[Chevron Cars Ltd|Chevron]] - [[Ford]] | South Coast Motors/BIC | 27 |- ! ? | ? | Mervyn Tunmer | [[March Engineering|March]] - [[Ford]] | ? | ? |- ! ? | ? | Fred Goddard | Palliser - [[Ford]] | ? | ? |- ! ? | ? | Gary Ainscough | [[March Engineering|March]] - [[Ford]] | Echlin Charger | ? |- ! ? | ? | Mike Domingo | Modus - [[Ford]] | Team Domingo | ? |- ! ? | ? | Alan Domingo | [[Chevron Cars Ltd|Chevron]] - [[Ford]] | Team Domingo | ? |- ! ? | ? | Joe Domingo | [[Chevron Cars Ltd|Chevron]] - [[Ford]] | Team Domingo | ? |- |} == Qualifying == 1. Roy Klomfass (F/Atl), 1.03.6
2. Tony Martin (F/Atl), 1.04.5
3. Dave Charlton (F/Atl, 1.04.9
4. Nols Nieman (F/Atl), 1.04.9
5. John Gibb (F/Atl), 1.06.3
No other driver posted a time. == References == [http://www.oldracingcars.com/results/result.php?RaceID=F76G OldRacingCars.com] [[Category:Motorsport in Rhodesia]] [[Category:1976 in Rhodesia|Grand Prix]] [[Category:1976 in motorsport]] [[Category:20th century in Harare]] [[Category:Sport in Harare]]

revision.text:
'''"2–0 lead is the worst lead"''' is a [[cliché]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Sports/proof-dangerous-lead/story?id=23820288|title=Proof 2-0 is a most dangerous lead|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2014-05-22|website=ABC News|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> used in [[sport]]ing contests,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.barrypopik.com/index.php/new_york_city/entry/the_worst_lead_in_hockey_is_a_two_goal_lead|title=The worst lead in hockey is a two-goal lead|last=Popik|first=Barry|website=www.barrypopik.com|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/4-reasons-why-2-0-lead-ice-hockeys-worst-aguilar-eli-mp-cpds|title=4 Reasons Why a 2-0 Lead is Ice Hockey's Worst Lead|last=|first=|date=2016-12-09|website=LinkedIn|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> to describe the situation in which one team is leading by a score of 2–0.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.goalden.com/2010/06/20-the-most-dangerous-score-in-the-game/|title=2:0 - TheNH most dangerous score in the game|date=2010-06-10|website=Goalden|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> The phrase is most common in [[association football]], where it is sometimes applied only to the scoreline at [[half-time]]. It is sometimes also encountered in other sports where 2-0 is a moderately large lead, such as [[ice hockey]].
==Concept== The underlying concept is that, a team which is leading 2-0 will be [[complacency|complacent]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kicker-conspiracy.blogspot.com/2007/06/most-dangerous-lead.html|title=Kicker Conspiracy: The most dangerous lead|last=M|first=Alex|date=2007-06-22|website=Kicker Conspiracy|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> and have a 'false sense of security' in their lead.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.impactmontreal.com/en/post/2015/04/03/2-0-clich%C3%A9-goes-most-dangerous-scoreline|title=2-0, the cliché goes, is the most dangerous scoreline|last=|first=|date=2016-12-09|website=Montreal Impact|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> If the trailing team then scores to make it 2-1, the leading team can panic and concede further, resulting in a [[Tie (draw)|draw]], or even a win for the other team. In contrast, a team which is leading 1-0 will tend to concentrate and play with intensity to protect or extend their narrow lead, whilst teams leading by three or more goals have a sufficiently large buffer that comebacks are unlikely.
The cliché may be invoked by coaches to encourage their players to maintain effort levels after obtaining a two-goal lead.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.soccerclassroom.com/coaching-blog/the-most-dangerous-lead-in-soccer-2-0/|title=The Most Dangerous Lead in Soccer: 2-0|date=2011-06-27|newspaper=Soccer Classroom|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> It can also be used in broadcasting, such as by a [[sport commentator|commentator]] or studio [[pundit]], to suggest that the final result is still in doubt, thereby maintaining audience interest in a game.
There is little evidence that 2-0 is the worst lead in practice. In football, a team leading 2-0 at half-time only goes on to lose the game in about 2% of cases.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2764974/The-time-Manchester-United-suffered-defeat-two-goal-lead-Margaret-Thatcher-No-10.html|title=The last time United suffered defeat after a two-goal was in 1984|newspaper=Mail Online|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/OptaJoe/status/805422534023872512|title=OptaJoe on Twitter|newspaper=Twitter|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> In [[ice hockey]], statistics show that if a team builds a two-goal advantage, they go on to win the game in the majority of instances, and that a one-goal lead is far more dangerous.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.puckscene.com/2011/08/the-most-dangerous-lead-in-hockey-fact-or-myth/|title="The Most Dangerous Lead in Hockey" – Fact or Myth?|date=2011-08-19|newspaper=PuckScene.com|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> As a result, the cliché is often used in full knowledge that 2-0 is not in fact the worst possible lead.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thepowerofgoals.blogspot.com/2016/03/martinez-blows-most-dangerous-of-leads.html|title=The Power of Goals.: "Martinez Blows Most Dangerous of Leads"!|last=Taylor|first=Mark|date=2016-03-06|website=The Power of Goals.|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/blog/2015/01/28/debunking-myth-dangerous-two-nil-lead|title=Debunking the myth of the 'dangerous two-nil lead'|newspaper=The World Game|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref>
==Examples of usage== The cliché was popularized by Czech football coach and television commentator [[Josef Csaplár]] in the Czech football community. His use of the term suggested that a 2–0 half-time lead could only end in a defeat and the cliché is known in the [[Czech Republic]] as ''Csaplár's trap'' ([[Czech language|Czech]]: ''Csaplárova past'').<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.o2sport.cz/fotbal/csaplar-efekt-se-nastesti-nepotvrdil-fotbalova-francie-vola-narodni-tym/|title=Csaplár efekt se nepotvrdil, Francie volá národní tým!|last=o2sport.cz|date=2015-09-07|newspaper=O2 Sport|language=cs-CZ|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sport.aktualne.cz/fotbal/bednar-a-lafata-si-prekazeli-plzen-skripla-csaplarova-past/r~2f013818132d11e3a431002590604f2e/|title=Bednář a Lafata si překáželi. Plzeň skřípla Csaplárova past|website=Aktuálně.cz - Víte co se právě děje|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref>
In [[Serbia]], the cliché is known for being used by manager and former player [[Milan Živadinović]].<ref name="Kako ono reče Živa">{{cite web |url=http://www.mozzartsport.com/fudbal/vesti/kako-ono-rece-ziva-2-0-je-najopasniji-rezultat/129469 |author=''Mozzart Sport'' |title=Kako ono reče Živa – 2:0 je najopasniji rezultat |accessdate=2018-07-15 |date=2016-03-04 |language=Serbian}}</ref>
The cliché was also used by Australian former player and TV broadcaster [[Johnny Warren]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.cz/books?id=VtiNXrFEJ4kC&pg=PA207|title=Offsider - a Memoir: How a Scrawny Pommy Kid Learned to Love the Socceroos|last=Mangan|first=Patrick|publisher=Melbourne University Publishing|year=2010|isbn=978-0522857214|location=Australia|pages=207|quote=At some stage in the previous twenty minutes, in the TV gantry not far of us, Johnny Warren no doubt uttered one of his favourite truisms: that a 2-0 is a dangerous lead. It breeds complacency, he liked to say. The Socceroos didn't needed reminding - now.|via=}}</ref> Television pundit and former English footballer [[Gary Lineker]] raised the cliché when commenting on a 2016 match between [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], in which Liverpool led by 2–0 at half-time but ended up losing 4–3.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38121184|title=Bournemouth 4-3 Liverpool|date=2016-12-04|newspaper=BBC Sport|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=25em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:2-0 lead is the worst lead}} [[Category:Association football terminology]]

{{Infobox football biography | name = Afrim Tovërlani | height = {{Height|m=1.71}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1967|1|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Pristina]], [[SFR Yugoslavia]] | position = Defender | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = 1985–1991 | clubs1 = [[FC Prishtina|Prishtina]] | caps1 = 28 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 1992–1993 | clubs2 = [[KF Flamurtari|Flamurtari]] | caps2 = | goals2 = |nationalyears1 = 1993 |nationalteam1 = [[Kosovo national football team|Kosovo]] |nationalcaps1 = 1 |nationalgoals1 = 0 | pcupdate = | ntupdate = 7/14/2015 | manageryears1 = 2007–2009 | manageryears2 = 2012–???? | manageryears3 = 2015–2017 | manageryears4 = 2018– | managerclubs1 = [[FC Prishtina|Prishtina]] | managerclubs2 = [[FC Prishtina|Prishtina]]<ref>[http://gazetaexpress.com/?cid=1,24,95158 Prishtina rikthen ikonën] Gazeta Express dated 25-10-2012</ref> | managerclubs3 = [[KF Feronikeli|Feronikeli]]<ref>[http://www.gazetaexpress.com/sport/zyrtare-toverlani-trajner-i-ri-i-feronikelit-150714/] Gazeta Express dated 09-12-2015</ref> | managerclubs4 = [[KF Ferizaj|Ferizaj]]<ref>[http://borozani.com/artikulli/toverlani-i-kthehet-superliges/ffk-superliga] Borozani.com 26-07-2018</ref> }} '''Afrim Tovërlani''' (Serbian language: ''Afrim Tovarlani'') (born 17 January 1967) is a [[Kosovo|Kosovar]] [[Albanians|Albanian]] [[Football (soccer)|football]] coach and a former football player.
Afrim Tovërlani became a famous football player in Kosovo while playing for [[FC Prishtina|Prishtina]] where he had an illustrious career. He made seven [[Yugoslav First League]] appearances for the club.
He played for [[Kosovo national football team|Kosovo]] in their friendly match against Albania on February 14, 1993.<ref>[http://www.rsssf.com/intldetails/1993e1.html 1993 MATCHES] at [[RSSSF]]</ref>
Tovërlani has also worked as a sports editor for the [[Kosovo|Kosovar]] daily newspaper [[Gazeta Express|Express]].<ref>[http://www.gazetaexpress.com/impressum.php Editorial staff of Gazeta Express] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629142351/http://www.gazetaexpress.com/impressum.php |date=June 29, 2007 }}</ref>

{{For|the parent multisport club|USC CSKA Sofia}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox Basketball club | color1 = white | color2 = red | name = BC CSKA | nickname = ''Червените'' (The Reds) | logo = CSKA 99-05.png | imagesize = 150px | leagues = [[A Group (Basketball)|A group(2 tier)]] | founded = 1948 | arena = [[Rumen Peychev Hall]]
(capacity: 4,00) | location = [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]] | colors = Red and white
{{Color box|red|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|white|border=darkgray}} | president = [[Robert Gergov]] | coach = [[Yordan Kolev]] | championships = '''12''' ''[[National Basketball League (Bulgaria)|NBL]]''
'''18''' ''[[Bulgarian Basketball Cup|Bulgarian Cup]]'' | website = http://www.cska-basket.bg |h_body = FF0000 | h_pattern_b = _whitesides | h_shorts=FF0000 | h_pattern_s = _whitesides | |a_body = FFFFFF | a_pattern_b = _redsides | a_shorts=FFFFFF | a_pattern_s = _redsides | }} {{USC CSKA Sofia}} '''BC CSKA Sofia''' ({{lang-bg|БК „ЦСКА София"}}) is a [[Bulgaria]]n professional [[basketball]] club based in the capital [[Sofia]] and part of the [[CSKA Sofia (sports club)|CSKA Sofia]] [[sports club]]. CSKA Sofia men's team have been champions of Bulgaria 12 times and Bulgarian cup winners 18 times. They play their home games at [[Rumen Peychev Hall]] in Sofia. In [[2006–07 FIBA EuroCup|2006-07]], they took part in the [[EuroChallenge|FIBA EuroCup]] tournament. ==History== The CSKA Basketball team took over the AC-23, a team which finished in the second place in the national championship in 1942. In 1946, BC "Chavdar" was formed and finished third in the championship. In 1948, the team was renamed as "Septemvri" under authority of the Central Military Club and finished in the second place. In 1949, the club won the golden medal at the national championship. In 1950, the team (again renamed as "Narodna voiska") was national champion and repeated the success in 1951. Altogether, the team has won 12 first places, 14 second places and 3 third places in the National Championship. The founders of the club are Kosyo Totev, Iliya Angelov, and Tonko Rainov. Within 1948–1974 period, 26 players of the club became Masters of Sports – an honorable title for the most skilled and distinguished sportsmen in Bulgaria. The most successful period of the club was 1990–1992, when the team became the national champion for three years in a row. ==Honours== * [[File:Gold medal icon.svg|15px]] ''[[National Basketball League (Bulgaria)|Bulgarian Championships]]'' (12): 1949, 1950, 1951, 1965, 1967, 1977, 1980, 1983, 1984, 1990, 1991, 1992 * [[File:Gold medal icon.svg|15px]] ''[[Bulgarian Basketball Cup|Bulgarian Cup]]'' (18): 1953, 1955, 1962, 1963, 1973, 1974, 1977, 1978, 1980, 1981, 1984, 1985, 1989, 1990, 1991, 1992, 1994, 2005 * European Champions' Cup 1/4 finalists (2): 1966, 1968 ==Notable former players== *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Dimitar Donev]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Kliment Kamenarov]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Georgi Maleev]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Tsvyatko Barchovski]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Temelaki Dimitrov]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Atanas Golomeev]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Petko Marinov]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Milko Arabadzhiyski]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Rumen Peychev]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Georgi Glouchkov]] *[[File:Flag of Nigeria.svg|20px|]] [[Omorogbe Nosa]] *[[File:Flag of Serbia.svg|20px|]] [[Allan Tošić]] *{{flagicon|Bahamas}} [[Trevor Harvey (basketball)|Trevor Harvey]] *{{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Leandro Palladino]] ==Notable former coaches== *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Lyubomir Katerinski]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Iliya Semov]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Kosyo Totev]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Tsvyatko Barchovski]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Omurtag Kuzmanov]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Petko Marinov]] *[[File:Flag of Bulgaria.svg|20px|]] [[Rossen Barchovski]] *[[File:Flag of Israel.svg|20px|]] [[Jaacob Gino]] ==WBC CSKA Sofia== Women's basketball team CSKA was founded in 1944. The team was formed after the merger of several AC-23 and other teams under the new name "Chavdar". This team existed only a few years, then restored again in the period 2004–2007. ===Historical name's and years of existence=== * AC-23 (1923–1944) * Chavdar (1944–1948) * Septemvrisko Zname/CDV (1948) * CSKA (1948–1979 and 2006–2008) ===Woman's honours=== * [[File:Gold medal icon.svg|15px]] '''[[Bulgarian Women's Basketball Championship|Bulgarian Championships]]''' (1): 2007 ** [[File:Silver medal icon.svg|15px]] '''Bulgarian Championships''' (1): 1946 * [[File:Gold medal icon.svg|15px]] '''[[Bulgarian Women's Basketball Cup|Bulgarian Cup]]''' (1): 2007 **[[File:Silver medal icon.svg|15px]] '''Bulgarian Cup''' (1): 1974 * [[File:Gold medal icon.svg|15px]] '''[[MŽRKL|Women's Adriatic League]]''' (1): 2007 ==External links== * [http://www.cska-basket.bg/ Official website] {{bg icon}} {{BG NBL}} [[Category:Basketball teams in Bulgaria|CSKA Sofia]] [[Category:CSKA Sofia]] [[Category:Military sports]] [[Category:Basketball teams established in 1948]]

(1993–present) | arena = Friedrich-List-Halle | capacity = 800 | location = [[Karlsruhe]], [[Germany]] | colors = Blue, White
{{Color box|#3333cc}} {{Color box|white}} | current = | sponsor = | media = | president = | vice-presidents = | manager = | coach = | captain = | ownership = | championships = | conf_champs = | div_champs = | website = {{URL|http://www.bg-karlsruhe.de}} | h_body = 3333cc | h_pattern_b = _basket_in_white | h_shorts = FFFFFF | h_pattern_s = | a_body = 3333cc | a_pattern_b = _basket_with_white | a_shorts = 3333cc | a_pattern_s = }} [[File:Europahallekarlsruheinnen.jpg|250px|thumb|right|A game in the [[Europahalle]] in the 2005–06 season]] '''Basketball Gemeinschaft Karlsruhe''' is a professional [[basketball]] club based in [[Karlsruhe]], [[Germany]]. The club currently that plays in the third tier level of Germany, the [[ProB]]. From 2003 until 2014 the team played in the [[Europahalle]]. After this stint, they moved to the smaller Friedrich-List-Halle. From the season 2003–04 until the 2006–07 season, Karlsruhe played in the [[Basketball Bundesliga]], the top professional league of Germany. ==Players== {{See also|Category:BG Karlsruhe players}} ===Notable players=== {{Basketball notable players criteria}} {{columns-list|colwidth=18em| *{{flagicon|GER}} [[David McCray]] *{{flagicon|SVK}} [[Anton Gavel]] *{{flagicon|ISR}} [[Anton Kazarnovski]] *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Troy DeVries]] *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Domonic Jones]] *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Michael Stockton]] *{{flagicon|USA}} [[Tarvis Williams]] }} ==External links== *[http://www.bg-karlsruhe.de Official website] {{de icon}} {{ProB}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Karlsruhe}} [[Category:Basketball teams in Germany]] [[Category:Basketball teams established in 1993]] [[Category:Sport in Karlsruhe|Bg Karlsruhe]] {{Germany-basketball-team-stub}}

'''Belay glasses''' are [[eyeglasses]] with [[Porro prism|prismatic lenses]] that are used by [[belaying|belayers]] in [[rock climbing]] to avoid the neck strain commonly associated with belaying.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tv.thebmc.co.uk/video/how-to-use-belay-glasses|title=How to Use Belay Glasses|publisher=The British Mountaineering Council|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Belay glasses lens.svg|thumb|right|Principle of operation of belay glasses. Light from above is reflected into the observer's eye.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belayspecs.com/index.php/details/how-belay-specs-work|title=How belay specs work|publisher=Belay Specs|accessdate=24 April 2015}}</ref>]] Belaying involves a person standing on a stable platform below a rock climber controlling the tension and friction of the climber's rope. Since this activity requires craning one's neck to look up at the climber, a common malady named "belayer's neck" can occur.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.climbing.com/skill/belayers-neck/|title=Belayer's Neck|work=Climbing|first=Carla|last=Cupido|accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> The prismatic lenses of the belay glasses are arranged so as to bend light from above through [[total internal reflection]] into the observer's eye, allowing the belayer to observe the climber while maintaining a comfortable head/neck position.
The design based on the eyeglasses frame provides for a split field of vision: * the central field through the lenses, providing a vertical view to the climber; * the peripheral field around the sides of the lenses, allowing the belayer to remain aware of their surroundings.
The first belay glasses were invented 2007 by climber Albi Schneider from Germany
<gallery> File:Port des lunettes.JPG|Belay glasses File:Vue à travers les lunettes.JPG|View through the prism </gallery>

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Metricon Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = Metricon Stadium logo.png | image = [[File:Adelaide v Gold Coast - Carrara crowd.jpg|300px]] | location = [[Carrara, Queensland|Carrara]], [[Queensland]] | coordinates = {{coord|28|00|23|S|153|22|2|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = 1986 | opened = 1987 (Redeveloped 2010–2011) | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Queensland Government]] | operator = Stadiums Queensland | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = [[Populous (company)|Populous]] (2010) | seating_capacity = 25,000 (2011–present){{efn|name=officialName1|The seating capacity was temporarily increased to 35,000 for the [[2018 Commonwealth Games]].}}
18,000 (1987–2010) | former_names = Laver Oval
Carrara Oval
Gold Coast Stadium | dimensions = 161 x 134 metres | website = [http://www.metriconstadium.com.au/ www.metriconstadium.com.au] | tenants = [[Gold Coast Football Club|Gold Coast Suns]] ([[Australian Football League|AFL]]) (2011–present)
[[Australia cricket team]] (2018–present)
[[Brisbane Heat]] ([[Big Bash League|BBL]]) (2019–)
[[Melbourne Stars]] ([[Big Bash League|BBL]]) (2019–)
[[Brisbane Bears]] ([[Australian Football League|AFL]]) (1987–1992)
[[Nerang Bulls RUC|Nerang Bulls]] ([[Rugby Union]]) (1983–1986)
[[Gold Coast Clippers]] ([[Australian Baseball League (1989-1999)|ABL]]) (1989–1990)
[[Daikyo Dolphins]] ([[Australian Baseball League (1989-1999)|ABL]]) (1992–1993)
[[East Coast Cougars]]/[[Gold Coast Cougars]] ([[Australian Baseball League (1989-1999)|ABL]]) (1993–1999)
[[Gold Coast Chargers]] ([[National Rugby League|ARL/NRL]]) (1996–1998)
[[Gold Coast Titans]] ([[National Rugby League|NRL]]) (2007)
[[East Coast Aces]] ([[Australian Rugby Championship|ARU]]) (2007)
[[North Melbourne Kangaroos]] ([[Australian Football League|AFL]]) (2007–2008) | embedded = {{infobox cricket ground|embed=yes | end1 = n/a | end2 = n/a | international = true | firsttestdate = | firsttestyear = | firsttesthome = | firsttestaway = | lasttestdate = | lasttestyear = | lasttesthome = | lasttestaway = | onlyodidate = | onlyodiyear = | onlyodihome = | onlyodiaway = | onlyt20idate = 17 November | onlyt20iyear = 2018 | onlyt20ihome = Australia | onlyt20iaway = South Africa | date = 17 November | year = 2018 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/australia/content/ground/56383.html Cricinfo }}}} '''Carrara Stadium''' (known commercially as '''Metricon Stadium''') is a sporting venue on the [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]] in [[Queensland]], [[Australia]], located in the suburb of [[Carrara, Queensland|Carrara]]. The venue is primarily used for [[Australian rules football]] and [[Cricket]]. It serves as the home ground of the [[Gold Coast Football Club|Gold Coast Suns]], who compete in the [[Australian Football League]], while also regularly hosting [[Big Bash League]] matches. Carrara Stadium received substantial redevelopment work prior to the entry of the [[Brisbane Bears]] to the [[Australian Football League|VFL/AFL]] in 1987, but following the Bears relocation to the [[the Gabba|Brisbane Cricket Ground]] in 1993, it was used for other sports including [[rugby league]], [[rugby union]] and even [[baseball]]. The stadium has hosted the opening and closing ceremonies of the [[2018 Commonwealth Games]] as well as the [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]] competitions. ==History== {{see also|Gold Coast Sports Precinct}} ===Early history=== In 1983 the [[Nerang Bulls RUC|Nerang Bulls Rugby Union Club]] was formed and were located at Carrara Oval. During 1983 the Bulls would field one senior team. In 1984 the Bulls would field two senior teams. The Bulls would spend two seasons at Carrara before moving to Glennon Park in Nerang in 1985. On 7 October 1986 it was announced that [[Australian rules football]] club the [[Brisbane Bears]] were granted a licence to enter the [[Victorian Football League]] for the [[1987 VFL season]].{{cite news|last=Smart|first=Nick|title=No longer a white elephant|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=27 May 2011}} Bears President [[Paul Cronin]] announced on 23 December 1986 that the club would use Carrara Oval as their home ground. The financial backer of the Bears, [[Christopher Skase]], spent $1 million redeveloping Carrara Oval over a 10-week period at the beginning of 1987 which included upgraded player facilities, seating for 6000 spectators and new electronic scoreboard. The [[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy Lions]] defeated the Brisbane Bears in the first VFL game played at Carrara Oval before a crowd of 17,795 on 19 April 1987.{{cite web|title=AFL Tables – Crowds – Carrara|url=http://afltables.com/afl/crowds/vn_carrara.html|publisher=rleague|accessdate=28 May 2011}} (The [[Brisbane Lions]] website records this crowd as unofficially 22,684).[http://www.lions.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/5085/newsid/23736/default.aspx 1965–1996: The Spirit Burns Brightly] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605110412/http://www.lions.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/5085/newsid/23736/default.aspx |date=5 June 2012 }} In 1989 the Brisbane Bears and the Albert Shire Council signed off on a 30-year lease for the ground with an option for a further 10 years. Following this announcement Christpher Skase orchestrated the installment of $6 million flood lights which were never paid for;{{cite news|last=Houghton|first=Des|title=Breaking the curse of Carrara|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/spike/columnists/breaking-the-curse-of-carrara/story-e6frereo-1225899937592|accessdate=18 September 2012|newspaper=The Courier Mail|date=2 August 2010}} upon the collapse of Skase's company [[Qintex]], he would flee the country to Spain and the flood lights would continue to be unpaid. Liquidators would attempt to extract money from the [[Gold Coast City Council]] for the lights, but after an unsuccessful trial it was found cheaper to leave the flood lights at Carrara Stadium. On 15 July 1989 the Bears hosted the first ever night match at Carrara against the [[Geelong Cats]] in front of a then record crowd of 18,198. Insufficient public transport to and from the stadium and the poor on-field performance of the Bears resulted in poor crowds at the Bears games and prompted the local media to refer to it as the Curse of Carrara. The new owner of the Bears, Reuben Pelerman, would lose a further $10 million between the 1990–1992 AFL seasons, and the Bears would move permanently to the [[the Gabba|Brisbane Cricket Ground]] in 1993, staving off media rumours of a merger with fellow cellar-dwellers Sydney to form a combined Queensland/New South Wales team, the Northern Swans, or relocation to either Tasmania or Port Adelaide. In 1988, Carrara Stadium played host to the very first [[Touch Football World Cup]] in which teams from Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea and the USA competed in the Men's, Women's and Mixed Opens as well as Men's Over 35's divisions. Australia won all four division finals which were all played against New Zealand. The [[Gold Coast Clippers]] played their 1989–1990 [[Australian Baseball League (1989-1999)]] season at Carrara before changing their name to the [[Daikyo Dolphins]] and moving to [[Palm Meadows]]. For the 1992–93 season they moved back to Carrara as the [[Gold Coast Cougars]]. The Cougars stayed at Carrara until the abolition of the Australian Baseball League in 1999. The [[Brazil national under-23 football team|Brazilian football team]] set up camp at Carrara Stadium for pre-tournament training before the [[2000 Summer Olympics]].{{cite web|title=Keen interest in Japan & Brazil|url=http://theworldgame.sbs.com.au/article/2000/08/28/keen-interest-japan-brazil|publisher=AAP|date=28 August 2000}} The Brazilians later commented that the surface at Carrara was one of the best in the world.{{cite web|title=Talks fail to quell sniping in Gold Coast turf war|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/sport/talks-fail-to-quell-sniping-in-gold-coast-turf-war/2006/08/06/1154802755426.html?page=2|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=6 August 2007}} [[File:Carrara stadium.jpg|thumb|The stadium prior to redevelopment]] The ground was owned by the Albert Shire Council and transferred to the [[Gold Coast City Council]] when the two local authorities amalgamated in 1995. The field is officially known as Laver Oval after long time Albert Shire Chairman Councillor Bill Laver. ===Growth=== Following the folding of the [[Gold Coast Seagulls]] in 1995 a newly formed Gold Coast rugby league team named the [[Gold Coast Chargers]] were created and began competing out of Carrara Stadium in 1996. They continued to use the ground until the end of the [[National Rugby League season 1998|1998 NRL]] season when they were excluded from the competition as a part of the rationalisation of the [[National Rugby League]]. Rugby league matches continued to be played at the stadium, with pre-season trials being played there annually from 2002 to 2005,{{cite web|url=http://www.titans.com.au/pages/page.php?page=28|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104030436/http://www.titans.com.au/pages/page.php?page=28|title=From Chargers to Titans, the story since 1998|archivedate=4 January 2007}} and NRL premiership matches played in 2001 and 2005. The ground's capacity was increased slightly during this time. In 2005 the NRL announced that a licence would be awarded to the [[Gold Coast Titans]], and that the stadium would be their home ground in 2007 until the completion of the [[Robina Stadium]], which was opened in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.titans.com.au/pages/page.php?page=36|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310204731/http://www.titans.com.au/pages/page.php?page=36|archivedate=10 March 2007|title=Carrara, Gold Coast Stadium}} In response to the NRL move, the AFL scheduled three AFL 'home games' for the [[North Melbourne Football Club]] and a [[Australian Football League pre-season competition|NAB Cup]] match for Carrara in 2007, and the [[Queensland State League (Australian rules football)|Queensland State League]] began hosting grand finals there. The Titans would play ten games at Carrara in 2007 and miss the finals. Following the conclusion of the [[2007 NRL season]], Titans managing director [[Michael Searle]] warned the AFL that if a team were to be started on the Gold Coast it would disappear into the Carrara 'black hole' within five years.{{cite web|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2007/11/17/5006_gold-coast-sport.html|title=Carrara a `black hole', says Searle}} In 2006 it was announced the [[North Melbourne Football Club]] would play nine home games at Carrara between the 2007–2009 seasons. Following the [[2007 AFL season]] the [[Australian Football League|AFL]] offered the Kangaroos a $100 million package to relocate from Melbourne to the Gold Coast and be based out of Carrara. On 7 December 2007 the newly appointed Kangaroos chairman [[James Brayshaw]] announced the club would not be moving to the Gold Coast permanently and would continue to be based out of Melbourne. Subsequently, the Kangaroos games played at Carrara after the announcement suffered poor crowds. The AFL released North Melbourne from the final year of a three-year contract after they drew just 6,354 spectators to their first home match at Carrara for the 2008 season.{{cite news|last=Barrett|first=Damian|title=Empty seats force AFL to pull plug|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/afl/teams/empty-seats-force-afl-to-pull-plug/story-e6frf9m6-1111116397227|accessdate=28 May 2009|newspaper=Herald Sun|date=21 May 2008}} [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]], [[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] and [[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]] subsequently hosted the remaining home games during the 2009 season. ===Redevelopment=== [[File:Sunny Carrara Stadium.jpg|thumb|View of the field and grandstand]] [[File:Adelaide v Gold Coast - Carrara videoboard.jpg|thumb|The videoboard.]] On 7 May 2009, it was confirmed that the Carrara Stadium would receive a $126 million redevelopment, providing a suitable stadium for new AFL club the [[Gold Coast Suns]].{{cite news|last=Rogers|first=Jenny|title=Canberra kicks in $36m for Coast AFL stadium|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2009/05/07/76535_gold-coast-afl.html|accessdate=28 May 2011|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=7 May 2009}} The last event at the old ground was Richmond vs Adelaide in front of 11,174 fans. On 30 October 2009, demolition of the old stadium began.{{cite web|title=Carrara Stadium redevelopment gets underway|url=http://www.austadiums.com/news/news.php?id=410|publisher=Austadiums|accessdate=28 May 2011|date=30 October 2009}} By January 2010, demolition works were complete.{{cite news|title=Timeline to birth of an AFL jewel|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=27 May 2011}} Foundations for the grandstands as well as construction for the player and corporate facilities began in May 2010. By October 2010, the eastern grandstand was nearing completion. Just three months later in January 2011 the whole [[horseshoe]]-shaped grandstand was completed. By April 2011, the turf had been laid and the {{convert|23|x|8.5|m|ft|adj=on}}, [[LED]]-powered [[High-definition video|high-definition video board]] had been installed.{{cite news|last=Smart|first=Nick|title=Room to a unique view|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=27 May 2011}} The redeveloped stadium cost $144.2 million to build and seats 25,000 spectators (with the ability to house an additional 15,000 temporary seats).{{cite news|last=Smart|first=Nick|title=Coast scores AFL stadium|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2009/05/08/76995_gold-coast-news.html|accessdate=28 May 2011|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=8 May 2011}}{{cite news|title=Games bid vital to Gold Coast's health|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2011/05/13/314975_commonwealth-games.html|accessdate=28 May 2011|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=13 May 2011}}{{cite news|title=Welcome to Metricon Stadium|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=28 May 2011}} The stadium features an AFL oval capable of accommodating an ICC-compliant cricket oval, an IAAF Athletics field and a FIFA World Cup football field, facilities for 2,000 corporate patrons, AFL team and officials’ changing facilities, AFL media facilities, and team and officials’ suites.{{cite web|last=Battenbough |first=Gemma |title=Watpac wins Carrara Stadium work |url=http://www.architectureanddesign.com.au/article/Watpac-wins-Carrara-Stadium-work/493622.aspx |publisher=Architecture & Design |accessdate=28 May 2011 |date=7 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706101120/http://www.architectureanddesign.com.au/article/Watpac-wins-Carrara-Stadium-work/493622.aspx |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }} [[Watpac]] were contracted for the construction, which was scheduled for completion in mid-2011. The stadium then played host to an [[International rules football]] in November 2011, with 12,595 watching [[Ireland international rules football team|Ireland]] defeat [[Australia international rules football team|Australia]] by 50 points to 29. MakMax Australia was contracted to complete the fabric roof of the stadium.{{cite web|title=MakMax to top off Gold Coast stadium |url=http://www.bpn.com.au/Article/MakMax-to-top-off-Gold-Coast-stadium/519722.aspx |publisher=Building Products News |accessdate=28 May 2011 |date=1 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706102428/http://www.bpn.com.au/Article/MakMax-to-top-off-Gold-Coast-stadium/519722.aspx |archivedate=6 July 2011 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|last=Smart|first=Nick|title=Final piece of puzzle exceeds expectations|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=27 May 2011}} The stadium was opened for an open day on 22 May 2011, before the first match on 28 May 2011.{{cite web|last=Rugari |first=Vince |title=Suns' stadium set to go |url=http://www.sportal.com.au/afl-news-display/suns-stadium-set-to-go-122790 |publisher=Sportal |accessdate=28 May 2011 |date=17 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521204941/http://www.sportal.com.au/afl-news-display/suns-stadium-set-to-go-122790 |archivedate=21 May 2011 |df=dmy }} The ground recorded its biggest ever crowd when 24,032 people watched the Suns play {{AFL Col}} in Round 16 of the 2014 AFL season, a game the suns won by 5 points. The venue hosted the [[2017 AFL Women's Grand Final|inaugural Grand Final]] of [[AFL Women's]] on 25 March 2017. The [[Adelaide Football Club|Adelaide Crows]] defeated the [[Brisbane Lions]] 35 points to 29. The Lions won the right to host the match, but Carrara Stadium was used because the Lions' preferred venue, the [[the Gabba|Brisbane Cricket Ground]], was unavailable. A men's [[QClash]] took place at Carrara Stadium on the same evening.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/afl/womens-afl/aflw-grand-final-to-be-played-at-metricon-stadium-between-brisbane-lions-and-adelaide/news-story/3ee8c064c43dab467653cc0b53b5cf95|title=AFLW grand final to be played at Metricon Stadium between Brisbane Lions and Adelaide|publisher=Fox Sports Australia|first=Sarah|last=Olle|date=20 March 2017|accessdate=20 March 2017}} The Gold Coast's successful bid for the [[2018 Commonwealth Games]] resulted in the stadium being upgraded to a temporary seating capacity of 35,000 which was dismantled after the Commonwealth Games and restored the capacity back to 25,000. The stadium hosted the opening and closing ceremonies of the games as well as the [[Athletics at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|athletics]].{{cite web|url=http://www.goldcoastbulletin.com.au/sport/afl/excavations-works-begin-on-gold-coasts-metricon-stadium-for-2018-commonwealth-games/news-story/bb6188d1e7cdda4610dfccf53628ffbd|title=Excavations works begin on Gold Coast’s Metricon Stadium for 2018 Commonwealth Games|work=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=13 September 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/commonwealth-games/43641418|title=Commonwealth Games: Gold Coast event starts with colourful opening ceremony|work=BBC Sport|date=4 April 2018}} ==Stadium uses== Carrara is the home ground for [[Australian rules football]] club the [[Gold Coast Suns]], who compete in the [[Australian Football League]] (AFL), and also hosts events such as junior representative championships and [[Queensland Australian Football League|QAFL]] games. ===Gold Coast Suns=== [[File:Adelaide v Gold Coast - Carrara media facilities.jpg|thumb|Media facilities at Carrara Stadium.]] The [[Gold Coast Football Club]] (nicknamed the '''Suns''') have played their home games at Carrara since mid-2011. The [[Queensland Government]] contributed $60 million towards the redevelopment of the stadium, increasing the capacity to around 25,000 of which 23,500 is seated.{{cite web|title=Gold Coast SUNS {{!}} AFL – Home|url=http://goldcoastfc.com.au/|publisher=Gold Coast Suns|accessdate=28 May 2011}} The Gold Coast City Council also contributed $20 million[http://www.goldcoastbusinessnews.com.au/process/myviews/gcbn_article.html?articleId=1411 GCCC to commit $20M to Carrara stadium] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141230042618/http://www.goldcoastbusinessnews.com.au/process/myviews/gcbn_article.html?articleId=1411 |date=30 December 2014 }} and the AFL $10 million.{{cite web|last=Walsh |first=Gary |title=Green light for Gold Coast |url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/74077/default.aspx |publisher=AFL |accessdate=28 May 2011 |date=31 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121006110513/http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/74077/default.aspx |archivedate=6 October 2012 |df=dmy }} The Gold Coast Suns played their first game at the reconstructed stadium on Saturday, 28 May 2011, in Round 10 of the [[2011 AFL season]].{{cite news|last=Whiting |first=Michael |title=Gold Coast's first Carrara match set for sell-out |url=http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/114245/default.aspx |accessdate=28 May 2011 |newspaper=AFL |date=19 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526192535/http://www.afl.com.au/news/newsarticle/tabid/208/newsid/114245/default.aspx |archivedate=26 May 2011 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Caroline|title=Suns want Irish game at Carrara|url=http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/suns-want-irish-game-at-carrara-20110509-1eft8.html|accessdate=28 May 2011|newspaper=The Age|date=10 May 2011}} The Suns lost the match against {{AFL Gee}} by 66 points. A round 18 game against [[2010 AFL Grand Final|2010 premiers]] {{AFL Col}} attracted a then-record crowd of 23,302, selling out two months before game day.{{Cite web |url=http://www.collingwoodfc.com.au/newsfeatures/news/newsarticle/tabid/5586/newsid/114592/default.aspx# |title=Gold Coast ticketing update – Official AFL Website of the Collingwood Football Club |access-date=2 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110526212412/http://www.collingwoodfc.com.au/newsfeatures/news/newsarticle/tabid/5586/newsid/114592/default.aspx# |archive-date=26 May 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} On Saturday 11 August 2012, the Suns won their first game at the venue, defeating {{AFL GWS}} by 30 points. Crowds would not reach in excess of 20,000 again until Round 12, 2014, when 21,354 fans watched the Suns take on the [[Sydney Swans]] in a game that marked the first time [[Gary Ablett, Jr.]] and [[Lance Franklin]] went head-to-head since defecting from their original clubs, as well as this being Franklin's first match on the Gold Coast as an AFL player.[http://www.theroar.com.au/2014/10/31/the-must-see-games-in-the-2015-afl-season/ The must-see games in the 2015 AFL season], ''The Roar'', 31 October 2014[http://www.goldcoastfc.com.au/news/2014-06-24/gold-coast-suns-set-to-break-crowd-record Gold Coast SUNS set to break crowd record], Gold Coast Football Club official website, 24 June 2014 The record crowd was broken in 2014 when 24,032 attended the Suns' Round 16 game against Collingwood, which the Suns won by five points despite losing their captain Gary Ablett to a season-ending shoulder injury.[http://www.theroar.com.au/2014/07/05/suns-lose-ablett-beat-magpies/ Suns lose Ablett but beat Magpies], ''The Roar'', 5 July 2014 ===Cricket=== The [[Gold Coast District Cricket Club]] was formed in 1990 and shared tenancy of Carrara Stadium with the Brisbane Bears.[http://www.goldcoastdolphins.com.au/content.aspx?file=13710|37130q GCDCC: History] They would continue to be based at Carrara until 1993 when they moved to [[Robina, Queensland|Robina]]. The stadium hosted an international [[cricket]] match between [[Queensland cricket team|Queensland]] and [[England cricket team|England]] in January 1991. Controversy fell over the ground when touring English players [[David Gower]] and [[John Morris (cricketer)|John Morris]] chose to go for a joy-ride in two [[de Havilland Tiger Moth|Tiger moth biplanes]] without telling the England team management and buzzed the stadium in the middle of play.{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/232946.html|title=When Gower's tour took off|last=Williamson|first=Martin|date=14 January 2006|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=5 March 2009}} Gower and Morris also posed for press photographs with the plane later that afternoon. Both players were subsequently fined £1000 for the prank, a penalty that could have been steeper had Gower elected to release the water bombs he had prepared.{{cite web|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/sport/cricket/remembering-david-gowers-famous-1991-tiger-moth-flight/news-story/92fc39d5ec5646554de93d0992ae2c8e|title=Remembering David Gower’s famous 1991 Tiger Moth flight|last=Williamson|first=Martin|date=16 November 2018|publisher=Courier Mail|accessdate=18 November 2018}} Carrara hosted its first international cricket match since redevelopment on November 17, 2018 with [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] taking on [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] in a [[Twenty20]] match in front of 12,866 spectators.{{Cite web|url=https://www.austadiums.com/sport/event.php?eventid=21032|title=T20I: Australia v South Africa {{!}} Austadiums|website=www.austadiums.com|access-date=2018-11-18}} For the [[2018–19 Big Bash League season]], Carrara will host 3 T20 games with 2 games hosted by the [[Brisbane Heat]] and another game hosted by the [[Melbourne Stars]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/big-bash-league-kfc-bbl08-schedule-fixture-broadcast-tv-radio-christmas-eve-tickets/2018-07-18|title=Big Bash League fixture revealed|work=cricket.com.au|access-date=2018-07-18|language=en}} The stadium remains a potential future home ground for a Gold Coast-based [[Big Bash League]] side that enters the competition.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/sport/cricket/big-bash-boss-believes-expansion-gold-coast-is-natural-fit-for-a-twenty20-franchise/news-story/469aeb7eea262168f3d31cc5884d465c|title=Big Bash boss believes expansion Gold Coast is ‘natural fit’ for a Twenty20 franchise|publisher=news.com.au|first=Ben|last=Dorries|date=6 October 2016|accessdate=6 October 2016}}[http://www.couriermail.com.au/sport/afl/teams/gold-coast/the-gold-coast-suns-want-their-own-big-bash-league-franchise-when-the-competition-expands/news-story/7fdb9e0a829a58cdb6f51e016b85d998 The Gold Coast Suns want their own Big Bash League franchise when the competition expands] ===Musical acts=== Carrara hosted a triple header of entertainment events on the Easter long weekend in 2001. The first night saw [[KISS (band)|KISS]] perform and become the first international act to play at the Stadium. Former KISS lead guitarist and foundation band member [[Ace Frehley]] revealed in his 2011 autobiography that he punched then-tour manager [[Tommy Thayer]] in the jaw while in the dressing room at the conclusion of the Gold Coast concert in 2001.{{cite web|last=Swansick|first=Tristan|title=Ace went down swinging with Kiss|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/ipad/ace-went-down-swinging-with-kiss/story-fn6cc53j-1226187095040|accessdate=20 November 2011|date=7 November 2011}} The stadium served as the venue for the last leg of the [[Kiss Farewell Tour]] and Thayer would later replace Frehley as the lead guitarist in the band. The next night saw rock legend [[Alice Cooper]] perform at the stadium. The third and final night of the long weekend saw the [[Anthony Mundine]]-Timo Masua boxing match take place at Carrara. On 10 December 2011 the [[Foo Fighters]] performed at Carrara and set the all-time attendance record for any event ever held at Carrara Stadium, 37,000 people attended the concert. The stadium is also featured in the Foo Fighters film clip of "These Days". Filming took place during the concert on 10 December 2011. On 19 January 2014, the venue hosted the Gold Coast leg of [[Big Day Out]] for the first, and last, time. ===Commonwealth Games=== [[File:Carrara Stadium, Gold Coast, Queensland 05.jpg|230px|thumb|Carrara Stadium prior to the opening ceremony of the [[2018 Commonwealth Games]].]] Carrara Stadium hosted the opening and closing ceremonies of the [[2018 Commonwealth Games]] as well as hosting the [[Athletics at the 2018 Commonwealth Games|athletics events]]. The athlete's village was originally going to be located next to Carrara Stadium but instead was constructed in [[Southport, Queensland|Southport]]. The stadium was temporarily upgraded to hold 35,000 people prior to the start of the opening ceremony.{{cite web|url=http://www.goldcoastbulletin.com.au/sport/afl/excavations-works-begin-on-gold-coasts-metricon-stadium-for-2018-commonwealth-games/news-story/bb6188d1e7cdda4610dfccf53628ffbd|title=Excavations works begin on Gold Coast’s Metricon Stadium for 2018 Commonwealth Games|work=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=13 September 2017}} ==Naming rights== The stadium lacked a naming rights sponsor in its formative decades, bearing the names Carrara Stadium and Gold Coast Stadium between its opening in 1987 and 2011. On 15 March 2011, the Gold Coast Football Club announced that nationally active home builder group [[Metricon|Metricon Homes]] had signed a $3 million, 5-year deal for naming rights of Carrara Stadium, to be known henceforth as '''Metricon Stadium'''.{{cite news|last=Smart|first=Nick|title=Metricon lands Suns stadium naming rights|url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2011/03/15/299455_gold-coast-afl.html|accessdate=28 May 2011|newspaper=Gold Coast Bulletin|date=15 March 2011}} In March 2016 Metricon Homes signed a 5-year extension deal with the Suns until 25 March 2020 for the naming rights of the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.goldcoastfc.com.au/news/2016-03-26/metricon-signs-fiveyear-extension|title=Metricon signs five-year extension|website=goldcoastfc.com.au|access-date=2016-03-26}} ==Transport access== {| class="wikitable" |+ Public transport access !Service!!Station/stop!!Line/route!!Walking distance
from Carrara Stadium |- | align=center|[[Surfside Buslines]] [[File:Aiga bus trans.svg|12px]] || align=center|Carrara Stadium || align=center|745 || align=center|50 m |- | align=center|[[Queensland Rail]] [[File:BSicon BAHN.svg|20px]] || align=center|[[Nerang railway station|Nerang]] || align=center|[[Gold Coast railway line|Gold Coast]] || align=center|2.0 km |} The nearest [[railway station]] is [[Nerang railway station|Nerang]], a 25-minute walk from the stadium. On match and event days, special shuttle bus services from Nerang station and Broadbeach serve the stadium. The shuttle buses travel along Route 745, a route that usually passes the stadium on non-match days. Future transport plans include a [[ferry]] service{{cite news|last=Potts |first=Andrew |title=Ferry plan floated for city |url=http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2013/08/14/456410_gold-coast-news.html |newspaper=Goldcoast.com.au |date=14 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020024000/http://www.goldcoast.com.au/article/2013/08/14/456410_gold-coast-news.html |archivedate=20 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }} and light rail extension that will stop at the stadium.{{cite news|last=Potts |first=Andrew |title=Westworld: Gold Coast’s western suburbs set to be linked to beach with light rail connection |url=http://www.goldcoastbulletin.com.au/news/council/westworld-gold-coasts-western-suburbs-set-to-be-linked-to-beach-with-light-rain-connection/news-story/c195c752a61e387cf31d282069c61c88 |newspaper=Goldcoast.com.au |date=18 September 2017 }} ==AFL records== ===Individual=== {{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} {| class="wikitable" !colspan=4|Most goals in a game by a player |- ! style="width:60px;"| Goals !! style="width:125px;"|Player !! style="width:100px;"|Club !! style="width:70px;"|Year |- | '''13''' || [[Peter Daicos]] || {{AFL Col}} || 1991 |- | rowspan="2" | '''11''' || [[Gary Ablett Sr.]] || {{AFL Gee}} || 1988 |- | [[Jason Dunstall]] || {{AFL Haw}} || 1987 |- | rowspan="2" | '''10''' || [[Simon Beasley]] || {{AFL Foo}} || 1987 |- | [[Jack Riewoldt]] || {{AFL Ric}} || 2018 |} {{Col-2}} {| class="wikitable" !colspan=4|Most career goals by a player |- ! style="width:60px;"| Goals !! style="width:125px;"|Player !! style="width:100px;"|Club !! style="width:70px;"|Games |- | '''119''' || [[Tom Lynch (Australian footballer, born 1992)|Tom Lynch]] || {{AFL GC}} || 59 |- | '''98''' || [[Brad Hardie]] || {{AFL BB}} || 45 |- | '''84''' || [[Roger Merrett]] || {{AFL BB}} || 44 |- | '''69''' || [[Gary Ablett Jr.]] || {{AFL Gee}}

[[Denver Nuggets|Denver Rockets/Nuggets]] ([[American Basketball Association (1967–1976)|ABA]]) (1967–1975)
[[Denver Spurs]] ([[Western Hockey League (minor pro)|WHL]]/[[Central Hockey League (1963-1984)|CHL]]) (1968–1975)
[[Colorado Rangers]] (IHL) (1987-1989)
[[Colorado Wildcats]] ([[Professional Indoor Football League (1998)|PIFL]]) (1998)
[[Denver Aviators]] ([[National Indoor Football League|NIFL]]) (2007)
[[Denver Cutthroats]] ([[Central Hockey League|CHL]]) (2012-2014)
Colorado Blizzard ([[Major Arena Soccer League 2|MASL2]]) (2017-2018) | seating_capacity = Concert: 10,500
Basketball: 9,340
Hockey: 8,140 | dimensions = 122,400 square feet }} '''Denver Coliseum''' is an indoor [[arena]], owned by the City and County of [[Denver]], operated by its Arts and Venues division and located in [[Denver]], [[Colorado]]. The arena holds 10,200 people and was built from 1949-51. The coliseum is located in Denver's [[Elyria-Swansea, Denver|Elyria-Swansea]] neighborhood. It sits where the [[Denver Pacific Railway]] broke ground on its Cheyenne line in 1868. Opening on November 8, 1951 with a six day run of Shipstads & Johnson Ice Follies{{Cite news|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2017/03/08/denver-coliseum-history/|title=Denver Coliseum’s glorious history spans music, rodeos, sports and much, much more|date=2017-03-09|work=The Denver Post|access-date=2018-11-30|language=en-US}}, today the Denver Coliseum is an integral venue of the [[National Western Stock Show]] and hosts a multitude of other events including: commencement ceremonies, rodeos, ice shows, motor shows, circuses, concerts, motivational seminars, dances, exhibits and trade shows. Notables include: [[Colorado High School Activities Association|CHSAA]] high school volleyball, spirit and basketball playoffs & championships, [[Disney on Ice]], The Denver March [[Pow wow|Pow Wow]], The Denver [[Coliseum Mineral, Fossil, Gem, and Jewelry Show]], [[Christian]] events, [[cheerleading]] competitions, and [[roller derby]]. When [[McNichols Sports Arena]] (MSA) opened in 1975, the coliseum continued as an alternate venue to the larger arena for events requiring less seating or overall space. This continues today after the opening of [[Pepsi Center]] in 1999 and the subsequent demolition of MSA in 2000. ==History== On January 10, 1952 [[June Haver]] & [[Walter O'Keefe]] hosted the official dedication of the Coliseum on the eve of the first stock show in the arena and over the years the Coliseum hosted many celebrities and artists including: [[Elvis Presley]] (April 8, 1956 - 2 shows, November 17, 1970, April 30, 1973); [[The Grateful Dead]] (November 20 & 21, 1973); [[The Who]] (December 4&5, 1971); [[Frank Sinatra]] (May 1, 1975); [[The Rolling Stones]] (November 29, 1965; June 16, 1972); [[Led Zeppelin]] (March 25, 1970, June 21, 1972, May 25, 1973); [[Stevie Wonder]] (opening for the Rolling Stones on June 16, 1972, November 3, 1974); [[The Lovin' Spoonful|The Lovin’ Spoonful]]; [[The Monkees]]; [[Cream (band)|Cream]]; [[Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young]] (November 26, 1969, May 12, 1970); [[Ike & Tina Turner]]; [[The Jackson 5]] (August 20, 1971); [[Black Sabbath]] (February 27 & October 18, 1971); [[The Moody Blues]]; [[Pink Floyd]] (April 17, 1975); [[Neil Diamond]] (May 8, 1971); [[Santana (band)|Santana]]; [[Jethro Tull (band)|Jethro Tull]]; [[Yes (band)|Yes]]; [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]] (August 2, 1972); [[Bob Dylan]]; [[Eric Clapton]]; [[Rammstein]] (May 20, 2012) and many more. The arena has been home ice to several hockey teams from various leagues including the [[Denver Cutthroats]] (2012-14), the Denver/Colorado Rangers (1987-89), the [[Denver Spurs]] (1968-75), the [[Denver Invaders]] (1963-64) and the [[Denver Mavericks]] (1959). The coliseum was also an annual stop for the [[Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus]], the host of [[World Championship Wrestling|WCW]]'s [[Spring Stampede (1998)|Spring Stampede]] (1998) and the [[Colorado Wildcats]], of the [[Professional Indoor Football League (1998)|Professional Indoor Football League]]. Incidents of note in the coliseum's history have taken place. Former President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|Dwight Eisenhower]] stopped in Denver on his tour of western states in support of Republican candidates on October 8, 1962. In 1976, a planned [[Marvin Gaye]] concert was canceled after learning that Gaye was at his home in Los Angeles sleeping, led to rioting at the coliseum, a series of lawsuits for fraud and deceiving ticket buyers, and giving the media a field day as the top story.[http://denverradio.tripod.com/kdko.html "The KDKO Story"] On April 5, 2005, after a [[women's boxing]] fight held at the coliseum, boxer [[Becky Zerlentes]] died of her injuries following a third-round knockout loss to Heather Schmitz.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/06/sports/othersports/female-boxer-injured-in-fight-dies-afterward.html|title=Female Boxer Injured in Fight Dies Afterward|last=Sink|first=Mindy|date=2005-04-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-12|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} [[Santana (band)|Santana]] played the Denver Coliseum six times, securing the title of House Band. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.denvercoliseum.com/}} {{CHL Arenas}} {{Denver Nuggets}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Colorado]] [[Category:Sports venues in Denver]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Colorado]] [[Category:Denver Invaders]] [[Category:1951 establishments in Colorado]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1951]] [[Category:Indoor soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Arena football venues]]

{{use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{infobox country at games | NOC = ETH | NOCname = [[Ethiopian Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1992 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.ethiolympic.org }} | location = [[Barcelona]] | competitors = 20 (14 men, 6 women) | sports = 2 | flagbearer = | rank = 33 | gold = 1 | silver = 0 | bronze = 2 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }}
'''[[Ethiopia]]''' competed at the '''[[1992 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]]. Twenty competitors, fourteen men and six women, took part in eleven events in two sports.<ref name="SportsRef">{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/ETH/summer/1992/ |title=Ethiopia at the 1992 Summer Games |accessdate=17 July 2016 |work=Sports Reference}}</ref>
==Medalists==
=== Gold=== * [[Derartu Tulu]] — [[Athletics at the 1992 Summer Olympics|Athletics]], Women's 10.000 metres
===Bronze=== * [[Fita Bayissa]] — [[Athletics at the 1992 Summer Olympics|Athletics]], Men's 5.000 metres * [[Addis Abebe]] — [[Athletics at the 1992 Summer Olympics|Athletics]], Men's 10.000 metres
==Athletics== {{main|Athletics at the 1992 Summer Olympics}}
'''Men's 5.000 metres''' *[[Fita Bayissa]] ** Heat — 13:31.24 ** Final — 13:13.03 (→ [[Image:Med 3.png]] '''Bronze Medal''') *[[Worku Bikila]] ** Heat — 13:32.93 ** Final — 13:23.52 (→ 6th place) *[[Addis Abebe]] ** Heat — 13:40.76 (→ did not advance)
'''Men's 10.000 metres''' *[[Addis Abebe]] ** Heat — 28:15.76 ** Final — 28:00.07 (→ [[Image:Med 3.png]] '''Bronze Medal''') *[[Fita Bayisa]] ** Heat — 28:23.55 ** Final — 28:27.68 (→ 9th place)
'''Men's Marathon''' * [[Tena Megere]] — 2:17.07 (→ 23rd place) * [[Zerehune Gitaw]] — 2:28.25 (→ 61st place) * [[Abebe Mekonnen]] — did not finish (→ no ranking)
'''Men's 20 km Walk''' *[[Shemisu Hasen]] — 1:32:39 (→ 25th place)
'''Women's 800 metres''' *[[Zewdie Hailemariam]] ** Heat — 2:03.85 (→ did not advance)
'''Women's 10.000 metres''' *[[Derartu Tulu]] ** Heat — 31:55.67 ** Final — 31:06.02 (→ [[Image:Med 1.png]] '''Gold Medal''') *[[Moreda Tigist]] ** Heat — 32:14.42 ** Final — 34:05.56 (→ 18th place) *[[Luchia Yeshak]] ** Qualifying Heat — 34:12.16 (→ did not advance)
'''Women's Marathon''' * [[Addis Gezahegu]] — 2:58.27 (→ 30th place)
==Cycling== {{main|Cycling at the 1992 Summer Olympics}} Five male cyclists represented Ethiopia in 1992.
;[[Cycling at the 1992 Summer Olympics – Men's individual road race|Men's road race]] * [[Biruk Abebe]] * [[Asmelash Geyesus]] * [[Tekle Hailemikael]]
;[[Cycling at the 1992 Summer Olympics – Men's team time trial|Men's team time trial]] * [[Biruk Abebe]] * [[Hailu Fana]] * [[Asmelash Geyesus]] * [[Daniel Tesfaye]]
==References== {{reflist}}

Those results can be found above in this article in the cross-country skiing section. Some athletes (but not all) entered in both the cross-country skiing and Nordic combined event, their time on the 18 km was used for both events. 2014–Present }} | embedded = | website = [http://www.rit.edu/fa/arenas http://www.rit.edu/fa/arenas] }} '''The Gene Polisseni Center''' is an ice arena on the [[Rochester Institute of Technology]] campus in [[Henrietta, New York]]. Ground was broken for the project on October 19, 2012, and the arena was officially dedicated on September 18, 2014.http://www.rit.edu/news/story.php?id=50983 The arena is the home of the varsity [[ice hockey]] teams at RIT, replacing the [[Frank Ritter Memorial Ice Arena]]. Ritter Arena continues to be used as an ice arena.Ice Hockey Arena FAQs http://www.rit.edu/development/giving/powerplay/about-power-play.php The Polisseni Center serves primarily as a hockey arena (for RIT varsity hockey and local youth programs), and it will also be a multi-purpose venue. The Polisseni Center is built not far from Ritter Arena on the RIT campus, south of the Student Alumni Union, replacing portions of parking lot U.RIT Selects Official Site for New Arena http://www.rit.edu/news/story.php?id=49217 ==Fundraising efforts== Fundraising was started with a $1 million [[United States Dollar|USD]] donation from Stephen and Vicki Schultz.From out of the 'Corner' and into the spotlight http://www.rit.edu/news/athenaeum_story.php?id=48003 Naming rights were given based on a $4.5 million [[United States Dollar|USD]] donation from the Polisseni Foundation (with backing from [[Tom Golisano|B. Thomas Golisano]])Future RIT Hockey Arena to become the Gene Polisseni Center http://www.rit.edu/news/story.php?id=48695 and were announced on November 11, 2011 during the men's hockey game against [[Air Force Falcons men's ice hockey|Air Force]].Naming Announcement Ceremony https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=izxXK-QVBxs With arena construction being an estimated $30 million, the funding of the project has been divided into two components. The first half will be borrowed against RIT's endowment fund (worth $544 million),As of June 30, 2009.{{Cite web| title = U.S. and Canadian Institutions Listed by Fiscal Year 2009 Endowment Market Value and Percentage Change in Endowment Market Value from FY 2008 to FY 2009| work = 2009 NACUBO-Commonfund Study of Endowments | publisher = National Association of College and University Business Officers | url = http://www.nacubo.org/Documents/research/2009_NCSE_Public_Tables_Endowment_Market_Values.pdf| format = PDF | accessdate = March 15, 2010}} and paid back with sponsorship and ticket sales. The second half of the cost is a [[grassroots fundraising]] effort called the '''Tiger Power Play'''. The Tiger Power Play is an effort to bring in both big name donations (like [[Tom Golisano]]) as well as garner support from students and alumni. Small donations could be made by cell phone text message. Larger donations have been working directly with school administration. Sales of nameplates for seats is also available, initially costing $1,000 per nameplate, and later reduced to $500.Take a Seat in the Gene Polisseni Center https://www.rit.edu/development/giving/home_makeagift_buyaseat.php [[J.M. Allain]], CEO of [[Trans-Lux]] and an RIT graduate, donated $1 million for a new video scoreboard. {{GoBoardGame}} A '''Go professional''' is a professional player of the [[Go (game)|game of Go]]. The minimum standard to acquire a [[professional diploma]] through one of the major [[Go organisations]] is very high. The competition is tremendous, and prize incentives for champion players are very large. For example, the [[Honinbo (competition)|Honinbo]] Tournament has a [[grand prize]] of about $350,000.
Almost all professional players are from China, Japan, South Korea, and Taiwan. This is because until recently, only China ([[China Qiyuan]]), Japan ([[Nihon Ki-in]], [[Kansai Ki-in]]), South Korea ([[Korea Baduk Association]] (Hanguk Gi-Won)), and Taiwan ([[Taiwan Chi Yuan Culture Foundation]]) had professional Go organizations. In 2012, the [[American Go Association|AGA]] Professional System was established in the United States. In 2014, the EGF professional System was established in Europe.
Professional rankings are separate from the amateur ratings (usually ''30 kyu'' through ''7 dan''). Professional rankings are ''1 dan'' through ''9 dan'' (sometimes written ''1p'' through ''9p''). In the past, a '' 1 dan'' professional was roughly equal to a (European) ''7 dan'' amateur. However, since the competition to become a professional has increased since the late-1990s (particularly in China and Korea), it has become the case that new '' 1 dan'' professionals are much stronger than they usually were in the past.
There have also been professional Go players from the West competing in East Asian professional associations, specifically Romania, Austria, Germany, Russia, Hungary, Australia, Finland and the United States of America.
==Reaching professional level== {{unreferenced section|date=December 2010}} Professional dan rankings are normally awarded in Japan, China, South Korea or Taiwan, through one of the professional Go associations. The attainment of professional qualification differs in different countries: * In China, a few amateurs are given the 1p grade as probationers, on the basis of success in amateur tournaments. * In Japan, student professionals are called ''insei'', and have to play in internal insei competitions to qualify; mostly they are adolescents, and must decide whether to continue based on their chances of a career in Go, or go to university. Insei rarely take part in amateur events, but some of the top amateurs are ex-insei. * In South Korea, four amateurs become professional every year, at the top of a ferocious league system of 80 aspiring pros. Once within the professional system, promotion is based on game results.
Most professional players begin studying Go seriously when they are children, commonly reaching professional status in their mid to late teens. Some rare students achieve professional status at a much earlier age, such as [[Cho Chikun]].
In order to qualify as a first dan professional (1p), one must have deep resources of game experience and study. In local positions, professionals are often on close ground with each other, understanding good [[Shape (Go)|shape]], [[tesuji]], [[life and death]], [[fuseki]] and [[joseki]] patterns. However, in global positions they often differ in ''positional judgement''—the global impact and interaction of josekis and differing importance of various parts of the board during the opening and middle game.
==Discrepancies among professionals== The strength differences between professional levels is usually considered to be no more than 2-3 handicap stones. Therefore, the difference between professional dan levels corresponds to about one-third to one-fourth of a handicap stone.
Each country has different rules for promotion. Ranks may, therefore, differ somewhat from country to country.
Professionals may also differ in actual strength for a number of reasons, such as promotion not keeping up with actual gains in strength, or the fact that professional ranks (unlike kyu or amateur dan) may rise, but never fall (even if the player grows weaker). This has posed some problems, esp. with regards to international rank discernment. There are currently over one hundred people who have the rank of 9p (the highest professional rank), though many of them no longer play competitively.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} A further distinction is that some 9p players regularly hold titles, others won some titles, some entered the title leagues, and many 9p never had the fortune to achieve any of the above.
Traditionally it has been uncommon for a low professional dan to beat some of the highest pro dans. But since the late-1990s it has slowly become more common. This trend has been primarily credited to the result of increased competition to become a professional player in China and Korea. The result, that new ''1 dan'' professionals are generally stronger than other ''1 dans'' in the past.
In Japan, the ''[[Oteai]]'' system was reformed in 2004. The goal was to help alleviate some of the rank inflation that had crept in over the years. Today's Japanese system uses various benchmarks; for example, winning certain tournaments or a certain number of games, to be promoted by a rank. The Korean and Chinese systems have also been similarly changed in the past several years. These systems have increased the importance of international tournaments by incentivising rank promotion through international placement. Recent criticism has been given to this aspect, arguing that an individual may increase many professional ranks at once through the virtue of a single competition result (such as [[Piao Wenyao]]).
==Pro and amateur dan== In theory, professional dans should beat all levels of amateur dans. In reality, the very top amateurs have proven very able. The conventional wisdom is that such players may achieve some of the insight of a pro, though perhaps not the detailed knowledge.
In China, Korea, and Japan, there are two distinct ranking sets, one for amateur players and one for professional players (who receive a fee for each game they play, bonuses for winning, and fees for other related activities such as teaching).
In the Japanese professional ranking system, distinction between ranks was traditionally considered to be roughly one third of a handicap stone (making the difference 3 pro dan equal to one amateur dan). The strength of new professionals (1 dan) was usually comparable to that of the highest ranked amateurs. Currently the professional ranks are assumed to be more bunched together, covering not much more than two amateur dans; so that pro 1 dans win some games against 9 dans. There are also a number of amateur players acknowledged as having pro 6 dan understanding of the game.
In South Korea, there are several amateur systems in use, with the recent introduction of official 7, 6 and 5 dan amateur ranks, each of which is somewhat stronger than the corresponding European grade. A 7 dan amateur will have won three national events, and will be effectively of lower-ranked pro standard. The older gup system does not easily match others. In practice, in Korean clubs, grades may be worked out against the resident strongest amateur.
The Taiwan Chi Yuan Culture Foundation also employs a dan system similar to that in Japan. It ranks its professional players from beginner dan (初段) up to 9 dan, being the highest.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://taiwango.org.tw/info.asp |title = List of professional players in Taiwan |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928224440/http://www.taiwango.org.tw/info.asp |archivedate = 2007-09-28 |df = }}</ref> However, the amateur ranking system is established by another organization which certifies amateur player through competitions, ranking player from beginner dan (初段) to 6 dan with 7 dan being honorary.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.weiqi.org.tw/default.asp |title=Taiwan Go Association |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927015754/http://www.weiqi.org.tw/default.asp |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref>
In Germany and the Netherlands a "classes"-system (German: "Klassen") was established by Go pioneer Bruno Rüger in 1920. It comprised a further subdivision into Kyu/Dan half-grades with classes 18 and 17 = amateur 1 dan with the 17 being on the stronger side. It was replaced by the Japanese amateur ranking system in the 1970s.

{{Unreferenced|date=July 2007}} {{Infobox stadium |location=Takamatsucho, [[Nishinomiya]], [[Hyōgo Prefecture]], Japan |opened=1937-05-01 |closed=2002-12-31 |demolished=from September 1, 2004 until summer 2005 |owner=[[Hankyu Corporation]] |image=[[File:Hankyu-Nishinomiya-Stadium-2.jpg|250px|alt=Hankyu Nishinomiya Stadium]] |caption=Hankyu Nishinomiya Stadium |main_contractors=[[Takenaka Corporation]] |seating_capacity=35,000 |dimensions=Left Field: 91.4 m (-1977), 101 m (1978-)
Center Field: 118.9 m
Right Field: 91.4 m (-1977), 101 m (1978-) |tenants=Hankyu Braves ([[Pacific League]]/[[Nippon Professional Baseball|NPB]], 1937–1988)→Orix Braves (Pacific League/NPB, 1989–1990) |}} {{nihongo|'''Hankyu Nishinomiya Stadium'''|阪急西宮スタジアム}} was a [[baseball stadium]] in [[Nishinomiya, Hyōgo]], Japan. The stadium was opened in 1937 and had a capacity of 35,000 people. It was used as [[Association football|football]] and [[Rugby football|Rugby]] stadium too. It was primarily used for [[baseball]] and was home of the [[Orix Braves]] ([[Hankyu Braves]]), until they moved to [[Kobe Sports Park Baseball Stadium|Kobe Stadium]], in 1991. [[Queen (band)|Queen]] performed a concert here for their [[Hot Space Tour]] in 1982. [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] performed 3 sold out concerts at the stadium of her [[Blond Ambition Tour]] in April 1990. [[Michael Jackson]] also performed 3 sold out concerts at the venue during his [[Bad World Tour]] in 1987. [[Ayumi Hamasaki]] performed 2 sold out concerts at the stadium during her [[Ayumi Hamasaki Stadium Tour 2002 A|Stadium Tour 2002 A]]. The stadium was closed on December 31, 2002 and was demolished from September 1, 2004 until 2005. "Hankyu Nishinomiya Gardens" (see picture on the right), a shopping mall containing a [[Hankyu Department Store]], an [[Izumiya]] supermarket, [[Toho]] cinemas and dozens of smaller clothing, fashion and food outlets, was opened on November 26, 2008, on the vacant lot where the stadium used to be. ==See also== *[[Nishinomiya-Kitaguchi Station]] ==External links== *[http://nishinomiya-gardens.com/index.html Hankyu Nishinomiya Gardens official website] *[[:ja:ファイル:阪急西宮スタジアム.JPG|Picture of old Hankyu Nishinomiya Stadium]] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the

[[TiPPMIX]] }} The '''Hungarian Handball Federation''' ({{lang-hu|Magyar Kézilabda Szövetség}}, '''MKSZ''') is the national [[team handball|handball]] federation in [[Hungary]]. The Hungarian Handball Federation is a member of the [[European Handball Federation]] (EHF) and the [[International Handball Federation]] (IHF). Its headquarters are in [[Budapest]]. The federation organizes the Hungarian league ({{lang-hu|Nemzeti Bajnokság}}) for [[Nemzeti Bajnokság I (men's handball)|men]] and [[Nemzeti Bajnokság I (Women's handball)|women]], and administers the national handball teams for [[Hungary national handball team|men]] and [[Hungary women's national handball team|women]].
