revision.text:
In the sports of [[American football]] or [[Canadian football]], the act of '''icing the kicker''' or '''freezing the kicker''' is a tactic employed by defending teams to disrupt the process of kicking a [[field goal]] just prior to the [[Snap (American and Canadian football)|snap]]. Typically, either a player or a coach on the defending team will call a [[time-out (sport)|timeout]] just as the kicker is about to attempt a game-tying or game-winning field goal. This is intended to either stop the kick immediately as the kicker is mentally prepared, or allow for the kicker to kick immediately after the timeout so that the initial kick does not count, in an attempt to [[gamesmanship|mentally disrupt the kicker for the actual kick.]] If the tactic is successful, the kicker will miss the kick due to [[Choke (sports)|choking]]. Should the kicker make the subsequent kick, then the attempt to ice the kicker is considered unsuccessful.
This tactic is also common in basketball, known as '''icing the shooter'''. A team may call a time out just before the opposing team's free-throw shooter is given the ball on the final free throw, in an attempt to disrupt the shooter, typically if a missed free throw allows for the calling team to either have a chance to win the game with a successful field goal, or allows the calling team to preserve a lead.
One variant of this tactic, attributed to former [[Denver Broncos]] coach [[Mike Shanahan]],<ref name="nyt102107">[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/21/sports/football/21icing.html?_r=1 "Icing Kicker: New Tactic Has Drawn Double Take"] ''[[The New York Times]]'', 21 October 2007</ref> is to call time out from the sidelines just before the ball is snapped. This prevents the kicking team from realizing the kick will not count until after the play is over. However, this has the potential to backfire: the invalid first kick could miss or be blocked, only to be followed by a successful second kick.
==Effectiveness== In their book ''Scorecasting'', [[Tobias J. Moskowitz]] and [[L. Jon Wertheim]] analyzed “pressure” kicks from 2001 through 2009 while controlling for the distance of the field-goal attempt. They found that icing the kicker certainly does not produce the desired effect, and in some cases might even backfire. Moskowitz found that when an opposing coach iced the kicker with 15 seconds or fewer left to go in the game, those kickers tended to be more accurate.
A study was also undertaken by Scott Berry, a statistician and the former chairman of the Statistics in Sports section of the [[American Statistical Association]], and Craig Wood, a biostatistician, life-long Pittsburgh Steeler fan, who won the Inaugural Henry Hood Center for Health Research Pillar Award, was published in 2004 in the journal ''Chance''.<ref>Berry, S., and C. Wood. 2004. The cold-foot effect. ''Chance'' 17(No. 4):47-51.</ref> Berry and Wood looked at every field-goal attempt made in the 2002 and 2003 NFL seasons, including playoffs, and concluded that, for "pressure kicks" – those made with 3 minutes or less remaining in the game or overtime period which would tie the game or put the kicking team in the lead – in the 40-55 yard range, icing the kicker caused the percentage of successful attempts to drop by about ten percent for an average kicker on a sunny day. On shorter kicks, the effect was found to be negligible.<ref name="nyt102107" /><ref>Peterson, Ivars. "[http://www.sciencenewsforkids.org/pages/puzzlezone/muse/muse0905.asp Icing the Kicker]" ''Muse'' (September 2005)</ref><ref>Peterson, Ivars. [http://www.maa.org/mathland/mathtrek_11_15_04.html The Iced Foot Effect] ''MathTrek'' (November 15, 2004)</ref> However, the statistical significance of the difference found – which amounted to four kicks out of 39 attempts – has been questioned,<ref>Birnbaum, Phil. "[http://sabermetricresearch.blogspot.com/2008/01/and-old-icing-kicker-study.html And (sic) old 'icing the kicker' study]" ''Sabermetric Research'' (January 6, 2008)</ref> and an examination by Nick Stamms of [[STATS, Inc.]] found that "pressure kicks" (defined as above except within two minutes, not three) in the NFL regular season from 1991 to 2005 showed an insignificant difference between non-iced kicks (457 out of 637, or 71.7%) and iced kicks (152 out of 211 or 72%).<ref>Zimmerman, Paul. "[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2005/writers/dr_z/01/21/mailbag.z/index.html Icing on the cake]" [[Si.com]] (January 21, 2005)</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{American football strategy}}
[[Category:American football strategy]]

[[File:John Frederick Sackville, 3rd Duke of Dorset by Sir Joshua Reynolds.png|thumb|200px|The Duke of Dorset]] '''John Frederick Sackville, 3rd Duke of Dorset''', [[Order of the Garter|KG]] (24 March 1745 – 19 July 1799) was the only son of [[Lord John Philip Sackville]], second son of [[Lionel Sackville, 1st Duke of Dorset]]. He succeeded to the dukedom in 1769 on the death of his uncle, [[Charles Sackville, 2nd Duke of Dorset]]. He was the [[British Ambassador to France]] between 1783 and 1789 in the lead up to the [[French Revolution]].
He is best remembered for his love of [[cricket]]. He was both a good player and an important patron, but his interest was sharpened by gambling, cricket being a major attraction for gamblers throughout the 18th century. His other sporting interests included [[billiards]] and [[tennis]], he also acquired a reputation as a womaniser.
==Politics== He was returned unopposed as the [[Member of Parliament]] for the county of [[Kent (UK Parliament constituency)|Kent]] in 1768, sitting until he became the 3rd Duke of Dorset on the death of his uncle in 1769.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1754-1790/member/sackville-john-frederick-1745-99|title=SACKVILLE, John Frederick (1745-99).|publisher= History of Parliament Online|accessdate= 21 June 2016}}</ref>
He was appointed [[Lord Lieutenant of Kent]] in 1769, a position he held until 1797. He was [[Captain of the Yeomen of the Guard]] from 1789 until his death.
==Cricket== The young John Sackville was schooled at [[Westminster School|Westminster]], where he first became a noted proponent of cricket. He went on to join [[Hambledon Cricket Club]], based in [[Hambledon, Hampshire]], which was the leading cricket club of the day. He was joined there by [[Sir Horatio Mann]], a [[Charterhouse School|Carthusian]], and [[Charles Bennet, 4th Earl of Tankerville|Lord Tankerville]] of [[Eton College|Eton]] and [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]], who was his keenest rival.
Dorset gained a reputation as a keen competitor. The ''[[Morning Post]]'' in 1773 wrote: "The Duke...having run a considerable number of notches from off strokes, the opposing fielders very unpolitely swarmed round his bat so close as to impede his making a full stroke; his Grace gently expostulated with them on this unfair mode, and pointed out their danger, which having no effect, he, with proper spirit made full play at a ball and in so doing brought one of the gentlemen to the ground".<ref name=GB18>[[G. B. Buckley]], ''Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket'', Cotterell, 1935.</ref>
In the same year, Dorset presented the [[Vine Cricket Ground]], [[Sevenoaks]], [[Kent]], to the town, at a peppercorn rent, literally. It is one of the oldest cricket grounds in England. The first nationally reported cricket match had taken place here in the [[1734 English cricket season|1734 season]] when "The Gentlemen of Kent" beat "The Gentlemen of Sussex". Sevenoaks Town Council still has the Vine Cricket Club, though the rent doubled to two peppercorns after the pavilion was built in the 19th century. They must also pay the [[Baron Sackville|Lord Sackville]] (if asked) one cricket ball on 21 July each year.
In 1775, a full-scale riot broke out at the [[Artillery Ground]] when Dorset's side was not performing too well. In 1782 the ''[[Morning Chronicle]]'' noted that "His Grace is one of the few noblemen who endeavour to combine the elegance of modern luxury with the more manly sports of the old English times".
Dorset's patronage of cricket was expensive — the ''[[Whitehall Evening Post]]'' in 1783 noted that the cost to Dorset of maintaining his team, before bets, was £1,000 a year. This was a lot, but less than the amounts some of his contemporaries were spending on racing. The report went to say that Dorset was unrivalled (among noblemen) "at cricket, tennis and billiards".<ref name=PVC>[[G. B. Buckley]], ''Fresh Light on Pre-Victorian Cricket'', Cotterell, 1937.</ref>
==Ambassador to France== In 1784 Dorset moved to [[Paris]], surprising his critics with newfound public dedication, to serve as ambassador to [[France]]. On 16 July 1789, two days after the [[Storming of the Bastille]] he reported to [[Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs]] [[Francis Osborne, 5th Duke of Leeds]], "Thus, my Lord, the greatest revolution that we know anything of has been effected with, comparatively speaking—if the magnitude of the event is considered—the loss of very few lives. From this moment we may consider France as a free country, the King a very limited monarch, and the nobility as reduced to a level with the rest of the nation.<ref>Wikisource, https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Englishmen_in_the_French_Revolution/Chapter_II</ref>"
He continued to promote cricket amongst the locals and British expatriates. In 1786 ''[[The Times]]'' reported on a cricket match played by some English gentlemen in the [[Champs-Elysées]]:
:''His Grace of Dorset was, as usual, the most distinguished for skill and activity. The French, however, cannot imitate us in such vigorous exertions of the body, so that we seldom see them enter the lists''.
The following year ''The Times'' noted that horse-racing was losing popularity in France, with cricket, on Dorset's recommendation, taking its place. In 1789 Dorset planned what might have become the first international cricket tour. His touring side, which included [[William Yalden]], [[William Bedster]] and [[Lumpy Stevens]], got as far as congregating on 10 August at [[Dover]]. But the [[French Revolution]] meant that they never got to France, thereby making his tour the first international cricket tour to be cancelled for political reasons. Just as the [[American Civil War]] 80 or so years later destroyed the prospect of cricket becoming popular there, so the [[French Revolution]] destroyed any footholds the game had in France.
Back in England, Dorset became one of the first members of the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]]; his public life continued in the post of Steward of the Royal Household — in which capacity his main role was to keep an eye on the dissolute Prince of Wales, the future [[George IV of the United Kingdom|George IV]].
==Personal life==
Dorset was a notorious womanizer. [[Augustus FitzRoy, 3rd Duke of Grafton]] became [[Prime Minister]] and his mistress [[Anne Parsons]] had the influence, if not the position, of a [[First Lady]] in her country. The Duke divorced his wife on the 23 March 1769.<ref name=odnbfitz>Peter Durrant, ‘FitzRoy, Augustus Henry, third duke of Grafton (1735–1811)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Oct 2008 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/9628, accessed 14 Feb 2017]</ref> Parsons may have become the First Minister's wife had he not discovered that Parsons was having an affair with Sackville.<ref name=odnb>A. A. Hanham, ‘Parsons, Anne [Nancy] married name Anne Maynard, Viscountess Maynard] (c.1735–1814/15)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, May 2005 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/75617, accessed 14 Feb 2017]</ref> [[file:Mrs. Horton, Later Viscountess Maynard by Joshua Reynolds.jpg|thumb|left|Anne Parsons was about to be the First Minister's wife until she met Sackville]]
Sackville's best-known and most enduring mistress was the Venetian ballerina [[Giovanna Baccelli|Giovanna Zanerini]], who was the principal ballerina at the [[Her Majesty's Theatre|King's Theatre, Haymarket]], and used the stage name [[Giovanna Baccelli]].<ref>[http://royalfavourites.blogspot.in/2012/08/gabriel-to-guyonne.html Giovanna Baccelli (1753-1801)]: Born Giovanna Francesca Antonia Giuseppe Zanerini. a.k.a. La Baccelli, Jannette.</ref> Dorset commissioned a painting of her in 1780–81 from [[Thomas Gainsborough]], which is reckoned to be one of Gainsborough's later masterpieces. He also commissioned a painting by [[Joshua Reynolds]] and a sculpture showing her nude and prone on a divan and cushions; this is still to be found at [[Knole House|Knole]]. When made Ambassador to France, Dorset even took her to Paris with him, and she danced at the Opera by invitation. (When he was made [[Order of the Garter|Knight of the Garter]] (KG), she wore the blue ribbon of the Garter while dancing)<ref>Jeremy Black. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=gkplT_eNMabKiALx8f2iDw&sqi=2&id=_anug566SpAC&dq=Giovanna+Zanerini%2C+Venetian+ballerina&q=mistress#v=snippet&q=mistress&f=false ''British Diplomats and Diplomacy: 1688-1800''] University of Exeter Press, 2001 - 244 pages p. 107</ref> Dorset and Giovanna had a son together: John Frederick Sackville (1778–1796), who was raised by his father at Paris and Knole after the couple parted in 1789.<ref>Sackville-West, Robert (2010) Inheritance: The Story of Knole and the Sackvilles. Walker & Co., New York</ref><ref>This illegitimate son himself fathered an illegitimate son Sackville Sackville who died without issue. Giovanna herself had a relationship with [[Henry Herbert, 10th Earl of Pembroke]] (d. 1794) until his death, and finally with a Mr. James Carey, with whom she remained until her death in 1801. This [http://albumvenitien.blogspot.ca/2011/09/giovanna-baccelli.html French blog] claims that she married Carey, and that Dorset made her an annuity of 400 pounds.</ref>
The Duke was also known for his affair (ca. 1777–1779) with the [[Elizabeth Smith-Stanley, Countess of Derby|Countess of Derby]], and briefly (ca. 1784) with [[Lady Elizabeth Foster]], daughter of [[Frederick Hervey, 4th Earl of Bristol]] and mistress of [[William Cavendish, 5th Duke of Devonshire]]. The first affair was notable because it did not lead to a divorce. The Countess of Derby was born Lady Elizabeth Hamilton, the only daughter of the [[James Hamilton, 6th Duke of Hamilton|6th Duke of Hamilton]] and the beauty [[Elizabeth Campbell, 1st Baroness Hamilton|Elizabeth Gunning]].<ref>The young Duke of Dorset, who had just inherited his title, had courted her in 1770 but failed to follow through to a betrothal. In fact, he left for France with his then-mistress Mrs [[Nancy Horton]] (Nancy Maynard), formerly mistress of [[Augustus Fitzroy, 3rd Duke of Grafton|the newly re-married Duke of Grafton]]. Her mother, now Duchess of Argyll, persuaded her to choose another suitor [[Edward Smith-Stanley, 12th Earl of Derby]] who would make a better husband. The couple who married in 1774 produced two children, [[Edward Stanley, 13th Earl of Derby|a son and heir]] (b. 1775) and a daughter Charlotte (ca 1776-1805). By 1777, Dorset had returned from the Continent and the relationship was revived via Lady Derby's participation in the first women's cricket match.
At this time, the Earl of Derby began courting the beautiful actress [[Elizabeth Farren|Eliza Farren]] (later his second wife in 1798), and perhaps this combined with Dorset's personal attractions convinced Lady Betty to succumb to Dorset. Her [http://www.thepeerage.com/p1391.htm#i13907 second daughter Elizabeth Henrietta] (born ca 1778–1857) was popularly supposed to be fathered by Dorset; the Earl acknowledged the child, but Lady Derby slipped off to the up-and-coming resort [[Brighton|Brighthelmstone]] which was conveniently near [[Knole House|Knole]]. By 1779, Dorset and the pregnant Lady Derby eloped.</ref> However, the Earl of Derby refused to divorce his errant wife. This meant that Lady Derby was ostracized for the remainder of her life,<ref>Georgian (18th century) social mores were less rigid than Regency or Victorian social mores. Only the Court and the most rigid families refused to receive women who had been divorced and had subsequently married respectably. By 1804, this was beginning to change, when the new [[Elizabeth Fox, Lady Holland|Lady Holland]] was not received after she was divorced and remarried to her lover [[Henry Fox, 3rd Baron Holland|Lord Holland]]. However, fashionable men and a few ladies still visited Holland House.</ref> and Dorset soon lost interest and abandoned his lover. He was received back into society, and even received by his former mistress's betrayed husband Lord Derby.
==Marriage and descendants== [[File:Knole, Sevenoaks in Kent - March 2009.jpg|thumb|Knole House, near Sevenoaks, Kent]] In 1790, after returning from France, Dorset married twenty-three-year-old Arabella Diana Cope (1767-1825), daughter and co-heiress of [[Sir Charles Cope, 2nd Baronet]], and stepdaughter of [[Charles Jenkinson, 1st Earl of Liverpool]].<ref> By his first marriage in 1769 to the Anglo-Indian heiress Amelia Watts, he was father of the Prime Minister [[Robert Jenkinson, 2nd Earl of Liverpool|Lord Liverpool]]. Her half-brother [[Charles Jenkinson, 3rd Earl of Liverpool]] (1784-1851) is the ancestor via his daughter Lady Selina Foljambe and [[Cecil Foljambe, 1st Earl of Liverpool|her eldest son]] of the present [[Earl of Liverpool]]</ref> Dorset and Arabella had one son together, [[George Sackville, 4th Duke of Dorset|George John Frederick]], who was born on 15 November 1793, and two daughters, Lady Mary Sackville, born on 30 July 1792, and Lady Elizabeth Sackville, born on 11 August 1795. The Duke died in 1799, aged 54, and left a life interest in his estates and free disposition thereof (in case of the death of their young son) to his wife. At his death, Arabella, Duchess of Dorset was thus a very wealthy heiress and from 1799 until her own death in 1825, Arabella, Duchess of Dorset (as she preferred to be known) controlled the Sackville estates and wealth in trust for their son. She remarried 1801 Charles Whitworth, who became 1st Earl of Whitworth, but had no further issue.
George '''John''' Frederick became the 4th Duke of Dorset on his father's death at the family seat, [[Knole House]], near [[Sevenoaks]], [[Kent]] at the age of only 6 but spent the rest of his life under the legal and financial control of his mother and stepfather. He died in a riding accident in Ireland, aged 21 having just become engaged to Lady Elizabeth Thynne (b. 1795), elder daughter of [[Thomas Thynne, 2nd Marquess of Bath]]. (She went on to marry October 1816 [[John Campbell, 1st Earl Cawdor|Lord Cawdor]] and have many children). Although the dukedom passed to his cousin [[Charles Sackville-Germain, 5th Duke of Dorset|Charles, Viscount Sackville]], the estates remained at the disposition of Arabella until her own death in 1825, when Knole went to her elder daughter Mary, Countess of Plymouth, and [[Buckhurst Park, Sussex|Buckhurst]] and the Middlesex lands (of the Cranfield family) to her younger daughter Elizabeth, Countess De La Warr. [[File:Stoneland lodge.jpg|thumb|Buckhurst House, Sussex (originally named Stoneland)]] Lady Mary Sackville had married firstly [[Other Windsor, 6th Earl of Plymouth]] (1789-1833) on 5 August 1811 and secondly her first husband's stepfather [[William Amherst, 1st Earl Amherst]] on 25 May 1839. She died childless on 20 July 1864, leaving her estates to her sister [[Elizabeth Sackville-West, Countess De La Warr|Countess De La Warr]] and her heirs male.
The Countess De La Ware was created Baroness Buckhurst in her own right (a title later inherited by a younger son Reginald who is ancestor of the present Earl De La Warr). Another line stemming from this lady is that of the [[Baron Sackville|Barons Sackville]], a title created in compensation for losing the Buckhurst title. The 1st Baron Sackville inherited Knole, according to the will of Mary, Countess of Plymouth. (He died unmarried, as did his brother the 2nd Baron). Their nephew, the 3rd Baron Sackville, was father of the writer [[Vita Sackville-West]] who created a garden at [[Sissinghurst]]. Knole House, still lived in by the Sackville-West family, and Sissinghurst, the family home of [[Adam Nicolson, 5th Baron Carnock|Lord Carnock]] have both been given to the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]].

==Further reading==

[[Ashley Mote]]), Robson, 1998. * [[H. T. Waghorn]], ''The Dawn of Cricket'', Electric Press, 1906.
===Miscellaneous===
* {{DNB Cite|wstitle=Sackville, John Frederick}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20011118235805/http://www.tate.org.uk/britain/explore/work06giova.html A database entry on the 3rd Duke of Dorset] (retrieved on 20 February 2005) * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20011118235805/http://www.tate.org.uk/britain/explore/work06giova.html |date=18 November 2001 |title=Tate Britain - Giovanna Zanerini }} (retrieved on 20 February 2005) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071008181258/http://www.sevenoaks-life.co.uk/index.php/article/articlestatic/69/1/1/ Sevenoaks Life - A History of Sevenoaks Town] (retrieved on 20 February 2005) * [http://www.artchive.com/artchive/G/gainsborough.html Archive page on Thomas Gainsborough] * [http://www.npg.org.uk/live/search/person.asp?LinkID=mp53591 Pictures of the 3rd Duke of Dorset held by the National Portrait Gallery] * [http://www.touruk.co.uk/houses/housekent_know.htm Houses in Kent - Knole]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Johnson Gymnasium | nickname = Johnson Gymnasium | image = Unm johnsoncenter.jpg | image_size = 225px | fullname = Johnson Gymnasium | location = [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]], [[New Mexico]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|4|57|N|106|37|5|W|display=it|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1957 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of New Mexico]] | operator = [[University of New Mexico]] | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[New Mexico Lobos men's basketball]] (1957-1966)
New Mexico Lobos women's volleyball (1996-present) | seating_capacity = 7,800 (peak) 4,000 (current) }} '''Johnson Gymnasium''' is a 4,000 seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]], on the campus of the [[University of New Mexico]]. It opened in 1957 and was the home venue of the New Mexico Lobos [[New Mexico Lobos men's basketball|basketball team]] until [[The Pit (arena)|The Pit]] opened in 1966. Today, Johnson Gymnasium is the home floor for the Lobo [[volleyball]] team. The gym is named after former Lobos basketball coach, [[Roy W. Johnson (coach)|Roy Johnson]]. On March 18, 2015, the arena hosted a [[New Mexico Lobos women's basketball]] game for the first time when the [[2014–15 New Mexico Lobos women's basketball team|Lobos]] took on [[2014–15 University of North Dakota women's basketball team|North Dakota]] in the first round of the [[2015 Women's Basketball Invitational|Women's Basketball Invitational]]. The team's normal venue, The Pit, was not available due to a conflicting [[Professional Bull Riders]] event.{{cite news | last1=Sickenger | first1=Ken | title=Lobos win nail-biter in noisy Johnson Center in 1st round of the WBI | url=http://www.abqjournal.com/557504/sports/lobos-win-nailbiter-in-noisy-johnson-center-in-1st-round-of-the-wbi.html | accessdate=May 19, 2015 | work=Albuquerque Journal | date=March 19, 2015}} The Lobos won the game and advanced to the second round where they were defeated by [[Oral Roberts Golden Eagles women's basketball|Oral Roberts]] at the same venue.{{cite news | last1=Tate | first1=Van | title=Lobo women’s basketball season ended by ORU | url=http://krqe.com/2015/03/23/lobo-womens-basketball-season-ended-by-oru/ | accessdate=May 19, 2015 | work=KRQE | date=March 23, 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.golobos.com/facilities/nm-johnson-center.html Venue information] {{University of New Mexico}} {{New Mexico Lobos men's basketball navbox}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in New Mexico]] [[Category:Defunct college basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:New Mexico Lobos basketball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Albuquerque, New Mexico]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Basketball venues in New Mexico]] [[Category:1957 establishments in New Mexico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1957]] {{NewMexico-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[UFC (disambiguation)]] (link changed to [[Ultimate Fighting Championship]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{notability|date=August 2016}} {{Discrimination sidebar}} '''Racism in martial arts''' has been a common allegation.
==Media portrayal== Some of this can be attributed to media portrayal of minority groups while giving the majority a primary role.<ref>{{cite book | last=Wilson | first=C.C. | last2=Gutierrez | first2=F. | last3=Chao | first3=L. | title=Racism, Sexism, and the Media: The Rise of Class Communication in Multicultural America | publisher=SAGE Publications | year=2003 | isbn=978-0-7619-2516-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YlmtnbRVz6oC&pg=PA96 | ref=harv | accessdate=2015-05-03}}</ref> Television shows such as ''[[The Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers]]'' have been called racist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2013/06/most-racist-tv-shows/the-mighty-morphin-power-rangers |title=The Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers - The 50 Most Racist TV Shows of All Time |publisher=Complex.com |date=2013-06-03 |accessdate=2015-03-14}}</ref> but, in the case of the Rangers show, a minority actor on the show attributes it to coincidence.<ref>{{cite web|last=Puga |first=Romina |url=http://fusion.net/story/6230/the-black-power-ranger-explains-why-their-colors-were-coincidental-not-racist/ |title=The black Power Ranger explains why their colors were coincidental, not racist |publisher=Fusion.net |date=2015-05-03 |accessdate=2015-03-14}}</ref> Quite often the media would portray Asians as being proficient in martial arts.<ref>{{cite book | last=Kowner | first=R. | last2=Demel | first2=W. | title=Race and Racism in Modern East Asia: Western and Eastern Constructions | publisher=Brill | series=Brill's Series on Modern East Asia in a Global Historical Perspective | year=2012 | isbn=978-90-04-23741-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HTMyAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA253 | ref=harv | accessdate=2015-05-03}}</ref> Ethnic groups and ethnic martial arts would be merged into one although they might be quite distinct.
==Alleged instances== Bruce Lee stated that racism was widely practiced in martial arts in Hong Kong.<ref>{{cite book | last=Wong | first=T. | title=Bruce Lee Martial Arts Training Revealed: | year=2009 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cf9-AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT88 | ref=harv | accessdate=2015-05-03}}</ref> Ron Duncan (an Afro-Panamanian), a founder of ninjitsu in America, discussed in detail the problems of racism in martial arts as he saw them.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kevin Bacor |url=http://www.sportintense.com/posts/professor-ronald-duncan-discusses-racism-in-martial-arts-and-black-men-in-martial-arts/ |title=Professor Ronald Duncan discusses racism in martial arts and Black men in martial arts | Sport Intensity |publisher=Sportintense.com |date=2015-02-13 |accessdate=2015-03-14}}</ref> Duncan explained how he believes he was denied recognition by [[Black Belt Magazine]] in favor of [[Steven K Hayes]] (who was white). The Black Karate Federation was formed by Steve Sanders and others seeking to have equal treatment of black fighters in Karate tournaments.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xdcDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA31&dq=%22steve+muhammad%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=c8MrVev7LIa2yQSpmICoAQ&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22steve%20muhammad%22&f=false|title=Black Belt April 1989|work=google.com}}</ref> This included allegations of biased officiating in martial arts tournaments.<ref>{{cite book | last=Green | first=T.A. | last2=Svinth | first2=J.R. | title=Martial Arts of the World: An Encyclopedia of History and Innovation | publisher=ABC-CLIO | series=Martial Arts of the World: An Encyclopedia of History and Innovation | issue=v. 2 | year=2010 | isbn=978-1-59884-243-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FaTfuuIlmqcC&pg=PA627 | ref=harv | accessdate=2015-05-03}}</ref>
==Current times== Fighters such as [[Maurice Smith (kickboxer)|Maurice Smith]] and [[Kevin Randleman]] were amongst the first black champions in MMA, but neither have received the media attention that fighters of other races have.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/extra/mma/news/story?id=4908823|title=Mixed martial arts has its own race issues to address|work=ESPN.com}}</ref> [[Joe Rogan]] of the [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]], has suggested that [[Jon Jones]], a UFC light heavyweight champion, isn't as popular as he could be due in large part to racism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmafighting.com/2014/9/9/6125107/morning-report-ufc-joe-rogan-jon-jones-racism-chael-sonnen-dana-white-tuf-20-mma-news |title=Morning Report: Joe Rogan attributes Jon Jones' lack of popularity to racism, believes Jones would be embraced if he were white |publisher=Mmmfighting.com |accessdate=2015-03-14}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Racism in sport]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Racism in sport]] [[Category:Martial arts culture]]

{{Infobox yacht club | clubname = Segelföreningen i Björneborg | emblem = BFS emblem.png | imagesize = | emblemcaption = Emblem | burgee = Burgee of Segelföreningen i Björneborg.SVG | ensign = Ensign of Segelföreningen i Björneborg.svg | nickname = | short name = BSF | founded = 1856 | location = [[Kallo, Pori|Kallo]], [[Pori]] | campus = | status = active | purpose = | chairman = | commodore = Pekka Koskenkorva | website = http://www.bsf.fi/ | }} [[File:Segelföreningen i Björneborg -sign in Kallo.jpg|thumb|right|sign in Kallo]] '''Segelföreningen i Björneborg''' ('''BSF''' for short), is a [[yacht club]] from [[Pori]], [[Finland]].
BSF was established on 26 January 1856 and it is the oldest [[sports club]] in Finland. The clubhouse is located on [[Kallo, Pori|Kallo]] island by the [[Port of Pori]], some 20 kilometres northwest of the city.<ref>[http://www.bsf.fi/ BSF History] Retrieved 9 June 2013.</ref>
The club hosted the 2006 [[Snipe European Championship]],<ref>[https://www.snipe.org/images/stories/EuropeanChampionship/2006%20Europeans.pdf Snipe Bulletin Fall 2006]</ref> and will be hosting the event again in 2018.<ref>[http://www.snipetoday.org/news/item/3115-snipe-2018-europeans-in-finland Snipe Today November 16, 2016]</ref>
==References == <references/>
== External links == *[http://www.bsf.fi/ Segelföreningen i Björneborg Official Homepage]

44,206 {{small|(2015–present)}}{{cite web |url=http://issuu.com/ucf_athletics/docs/2015_ucf_football_yearbook|title=2015 UCF Football Media Guide|work=UCF Athletics Association|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} | suites = 24 | record_attendance = 48,453 {{small|(2009)}}{{cite news|url=http://www.centralfloridafuture.com/ucf-blown-away-27-7-vs-miami-hurricanes-1.2024861 |title=UCF blown away 27-7 vs. Miami Hurricanes |work=Central Florida Future |accessdate=October 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708133204/http://www.centralfloridafuture.com/ucf-blown-away-27-7-vs-miami-hurricanes-1.2024861 |archivedate=July 8, 2011 |df= }} | tenants = [[UCF Knights]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2007–present)
[[Florida Cup (soccer)|Florida Cup]] (2017–present)
[[Orlando Apollos]] ([[Alliance of American Football|AAF]]) (2019–) {{small|planned}}{{cite news|last1=Steimle|first1=Kevin|last2=Breech|first2=John|title=Steve Spurrier announced as first coach and Orlando first host city for Alliance of American Football|url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/steve-spurrier-announced-as-first-coach-and-orlando-first-host-city-for-alliance-of-american-football/|accessdate=April 7, 2018|work=CBSSports.com|date=April 7, 2018|language=en}} | publictransit = UCF Transit Center, [[File:LYNX transportation logo.svg|50px|Lynx|link=Lynx (Orlando)]] | construction_cost = $55 million{{cite news |url=http://ucfathletics.cstv.com/genrel/070208aad.html|title=Bright House Networks Stadium Featured in SportsTurf Magazine|work=UCF Athletics Association|accessdate=July 26, 2009}}
{{small|(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|55000000|2006}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}})}} }} '''Spectrum Stadium''' (formerly known as '''Bright House Networks Stadium''') is an [[American football]] stadium located in [[Orlando, Florida]], United States, on the main campus of the [[University of Central Florida]]. It is the home field of the [[UCF Knights football|UCF Knights]] of [[NCAA Division I FBS]] [[college football]]. The stadium opened in [[2007 UCF Knights football team|2007]] as a replacement for [[Orlando Citrus Bowl Stadium|Camping World Stadium]] (then known as the Citrus Bowl) in Downtown Orlando, where the Knights had played since their inaugural season in 1979. The steel and brick-clad stadium was designed by [[360 Architecture]] and constructed in 18 months. The stadium underwent an $8 million renovation following the [[2014 UCF Knights football team|2014 season]]. The Wayne Densch Center for Student-Athlete Leadership was built on the east facade of the stadium, and a party deck was added to the east stands.{{cite news |title=UCF exploring open-air bar in Bright House Networks Stadium |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/blogs/knights-notepad/os-ucf-exploring-openair-bar-in-bright-house-networks-stadium,0,6449143.post |newspaper=Orlando Sentinel |date=April 2, 2012 |accessdate=November 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110202752/http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/blogs/knights-notepad/os-ucf-exploring-openair-bar-in-bright-house-networks-stadium,0,6449143.post|first=Paul|last=Tenorio |archivedate=November 10, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |title=UCF President John Hitt eager to open Wayne Densch Student Athlete Leadership Center |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/ucf-knights/knights-notepad/os-ucf-john-hitt-student-athlete-leadership-center-20141121-post.html |newspaper=Orlando Sentinel |date=November 21, 2014 |accessdate=December 5, 2014}} Since the renovations, its seating capacity is 44,206. The attendance record as of the [[2017 UCF Knights football team|2017 season]] was 48,453 for an October 18, 2009 match-up against the [[Miami Hurricanes football|Miami Hurricanes]]. The stadium is known as '''The Bounce House''', as it was found to be susceptible to considerable shaking when its crowd jumps in unison. Although it was stated that the stadium was structurally sound and that this effect would not cause long-term damage to the facility, measures were undertaken following the stadium's inaugural season to reduce these effects. ==Location== [[File:Knights Plaza Wide.jpg|left|300px|thumb|Knights Plaza, part of the Kenneth G. Dixon Athletics Village.]] Spectrum Stadium is located on the northeastern edge of UCF's {{convert|1415|acre|ha|adj=on}} main campus, which is approximately {{convert|13|mi|km|0}} northeast of Downtown Orlando and {{convert|55|mi|km|0}} southwest of [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]].{{cite web|url=http://www.iroffice.ucf.edu/character/current.html |title=Facts About UCF |accessdate=November 13, 2010 |work=UCF Office of Institutional Research |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415043957/http://www.iroffice.ucf.edu/character/current.html |archivedate=April 15, 2012 |df= }} The stadium is a part of the Kenneth G. Dixon Athletics Village and is bordered by McCulloch Road on the north side, [[Knights Plaza]] on the west side, and Orion Boulevard on the southern and eastern sides. To the west in Knights Plaza is the [[CFE Arena]], [[The Venue at UCF|The Venue]], [[John Euliano Park]], and the [[UCF Track and Soccer Complex]]. Also located in Knights Plaza are [[University of Central Florida student housing|The Towers residence halls]], housing 2,000 UCF students, including student-athletes.{{cite news |url=http://issuu.com/ucfmbbguide/docs/golf_guide|title=UCF Men's 2009-2010 Golf Yearbook|work=University of Central Florida|accessdate=November 13, 2010}} {{clear}} ==History== [[File:Bright House Stadium opening panorama.jpg|center|thumb|900px|Panoramic view of Spectrum Stadium during its inaugural game in September 2007]] On March 31, 2005, UCF received the results of a feasibility study it commissioned on whether it should build an on-campus football stadium.{{cite news |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/orlando/stories/2005/03/28/daily43.html|title=UCF gets stadium feasibility study|accessdate=October 6, 2016}} On April 14, 2005, the UCF Board of Trustees approved the construction of an on-campus stadium. The stadium, initially known as "UCF Stadium," was scheduled to be completed in time for the 2006 football season.{{cite news |url=http://stadium.ucf.edu/PDF%20Files/CHJC_UCF_Football_FinalReport_032905.pdf|title=Market and Financial Feasibility Analysis for the Development of a New Football Stadium|accessdate=October 6, 2016}} However, the Board of Trustees delayed construction until March 2006 due to the concerns from local residents regarding potentially falling property values and noise levels from the stadium. Construction on the new stadium began on March 22, 2006. The stadium was originally built without water fountains. The university argued that the building code used when the stadium was approved did not require water fountains. However, this claim turned out to be incorrect because the 2004 Florida building code (in effect in 2005, when the UCF Board of Trustees approved the stadium design) mandated that stadiums and other public arenas must have one water fountain for every 1,000 seats, or half that number of fountains if water was also available for sale.{{cite news |last1=Zequeira |first1=Claudia |last2=Zaragoza |first2=Luis |date=September 22, 2007 |title=Code group: UCF didn't adhere to water rules |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2007-09-22/news/FOUNTAINS22_1_bottled-water-coolers-drinking-fountains-water-fountains |newspaper=The Orlando Sentinel |accessdate=November 11, 2015}} On May 9, 2006, it was announced that the [[2007 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas Longhorns]] would be the first opponent for the UCF Knights in the new stadium. The game, the first of three scheduled meetings between the schools,{{cite news|url=http://ucfathletics.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/050906aaa.html|title=UCF Football to Face Texas in New On-Campus Stadium in 2007 - 2005 national champs will be first opponent in new stadium|work=UCF Athletic Association|date=May 9, 2006|accessdate=May 9, 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080318200616/http://ucfathletics.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/050906aaa.html|archivedate=March 18, 2008|df=mdy-all}} was held September 15, 2007. A sellout crowd of 45,622 saw the Knights put a scare into the Longhorns before falling 35–32.{{cite news |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2007-09-12/sports/UCFTICKETS12_1_season-tickets-ticket-holders-remaining-tickets|title=Full Up: UCF Sells Out 1st On-Campus Game|first=Kyle|last=Hightower|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=September 15, 2007|accessdate=September 15, 2007}}{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=272582116|title=Horns' McCoy, Charles team up to end UCF's upset bid|agency=Associated Press|work=ESPN.com|date=September 15, 2007|accessdate=September 15, 2007}} During the opening game, vendors ran out of water at halftime, leading to the hospitalization of 18 people for heat exhaustion. In order to correct the issue, UCF provided a free bottle of water to each person at the next game and immediately began work to install at least 50 water fountains throughout the stadium in order to comply with the 2004 building code requirement.{{cite news|url=http://www.wesh.com/news/14143574/detail.html?rss=orl&psp=news|title=UCF To Install Water Fountains in New Stadium|work=WESH|accessdate=September 18, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114074311/http://www.wesh.com/news/14143574/detail.html?rss=orl&psp=news|archivedate=January 14, 2009|df=mdy-all}} The stadium's naming rights were sold to cable provider [[Bright House Networks]], naming the facility Bright House Networks Stadium. In 2016, Bright House Networks was acquired by [[Charter Communications]]; in accordance with Charter's trade name for its cable services, the facility was renamed Spectrum Stadium in April 2017.{{cite web|title=Frost: Offense had their 'best day' in Wednesday scrimmage|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/frost-offense-had-apos-best-203842611.html|website=Yahoo! Sports|accessdate=May 8, 2017}} On April 7, 2018, the [[Alliance of American Football| Alliance of American Football (AAF)]] announced that Orlando would host one of the AAF's first franchises, the [[Orlando Apollos]], and that the team would play at Spectrum Stadium beginning in 2019, the league's inaugural season.{{cite web|last1=Kevin Steimle|first1=John Breech and|title=Steve Spurrier announced as first coach and Orlando first host city for Alliance of American Football|url=https://www.cbssports.com/nfl/news/steve-spurrier-announced-as-first-coach-and-orlando-first-host-city-for-alliance-of-american-football/|website=cbssports.com|publisher=CBS Sports|accessdate=7 April 2018}} UCF unveiled banners on Roth Tower honoring the team's conference championships, New Year's Six/BCS bowl wins, and their self-declared National Championship at the football team's 2018 spring game.{{cite news|last1=Adelson|first1=Andrea|title=UCF AD sees promise fulfilled as Knights unveil championship banner|url=http://www.espn.com/college-football/story/_/id/23279767/ucf-knights-unveil-2017-national-champions-banner-spectrum-stadium|accessdate=23 April 2018}} === Renovations === The stadium was designed for a planned expansion to 65,000 seats. UCF plans to begin the expansion by expanding the Roth Tower with more suites and club seating, and also adding an additional 10,000 seats in a third level on the east side of the stadium, increasing the stadium's capacity to 56,000.{{cite web |url=http://today.ucf.edu/staying-on-offense-70m-sports-projects/|title=Staying on Offense: $70M Sports Projects|work=UCF|date=May 4, 2010|accessdate=December 8, 2010}} The capacity for the 2015 season dropped by 1,117 seats when UCF removed seats on the east sidelines to construct the "Carl Black and Gold Cabana," which includes a bar, catered barbecue, and padded seats above the bar.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/12231943/ucf-knights-build-beach-club-football-stadium |title=Football, with touch of beach, at UCF |first=Darren |last=Rovell |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=January 26, 2015 |accessdate=January 28, 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/ucf-knights/knights-notepad/os-ucf-east-side-club-post.html |title=UCF's East Side Club gets a new name, new six-figure title sponsor |work=Orlando Sentinel |date=August 10, 2015 |accessdate=August 10, 2015}} In 2017, private field-level [[Cabana (structure)|cabanas]] were erected in the south endzone, adjacent to the new J. & J. Rosengren Lounge.{{cite news|url=http://www.ucfknights.com/news/2017/8/31/football-rosengren-lounge-field-cabanas-open.aspx |title=Rosengren Lounge, Field Cabanas Open|publisher=UCFKnights.com|date=August 31, 2017|accessdate=October 8, 2017}} In 2018, additional field-level cabanas were added to the north endzone, as well as Loge cabana tables along the top rim of the grandstands. In 2016, UCF removed its original scoreboard, located at the north end of the stadium, and replaced it with a full LED scoreboard measuring 114 ft x 36 ft.{{cite web |title=UCF Athletics bringing in larger, brighter LED screens for fall|url=http://www.news965.com/news/news/local/ucf-athletics-bringing-larger-brighter-led-screens/nrPr3/|date=May 18, 2016|accessdate=October 6, 2016}} One year later, UCF replaced the stadium's original auxiliary scoreboard, located at the south end of the stadium, and replaced it with a ribbon board that measures approximately {{convert|7|x|199|ft}}.{{cite web|title=Bigger Boards|url=http://ucfknights.com/news/2016/5/17/Bigger_Boards.aspx?path=general|website=ucfknights.com|accessdate=18 December 2017}} In 2017, the university sued the architects and contractors that designed and constructed the stadium. Cited in the lawsuit were claims of "defects and deficiencies" which ostensibly led to "premature wear of the steel," as well as visible rust issues.{{cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/classified/realestate/os-ucf-stadium-lawsuit-20170929-story.html|title=UCF sues over defects to football stadium|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|first=Mary|last=Sanklin|date=September 29, 2017|accessdate=October 9, 2017}} ==Attendance records== The highest attendance for games played at Spectrum Stadium against the Knights have included the [[South Florida Bulls football|South Florida Bulls]], the [[Miami Hurricanes]], and the [[South Carolina Gamecocks]]. {| class="wikitable sortable" ! style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UCF Knights|color=white}};"|Rank !!style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UCF Knights|color=white}};"|Attendance !!style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UCF Knights|color=white}};"|Date !!style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|UCF Knights|color=white}};"|Game result |- |1 || 48,543 || October 17, 2009 || [[2009 Miami Hurricanes football team|{{small|9}} '''Miami''']] '''27''', UCF 7 |- |2 || 47,795 || November 17, 2018 || [[2018 Cincinnati Bearcats football team|{{small|24}} Cincinnati]] '''13''', {{small|11}} '''UCF''' '''38''' |- |3 || 47,605 || September 28, 2013 || [[2013 South Carolina Gamecocks football team|{{small|12}} '''South Carolina''']] '''28''', UCF 25 |- |4 || 47,129 || November 24, 2017 || [[2017 South Florida Bulls football team|South Florida]] 42, {{small|15}} '''UCF''' 49 |- |5 || 46,805 || September 6, 2008 || [[2008 South Florida Bulls football team|{{small|17}} '''South Florida''']] '''31''', UCF 24 |- |6 || 46,103 || November 3, 2007 || [[2007 Marshall Thundering Herd football team|Marshall]] 13, '''UCF 47''' |- |7 || 45,952 || November 29, 2013 || [[2013 South Florida Bulls football team|South Florida]] 20, {{small|17}} '''UCF 23''' |- |8 || 45,671 || September 10, 2011 || [[2011 Boston College Eagles football team|Boston College]] 3, '''UCF 30''' |- |9 || 45,622 || September 15, 2007 || [[2007 Texas Longhorns football team|{{small|6}} '''Texas''']] '''35''', UCF 32 |- |10 || 45,510 || October 20, 2007 || [[2007 Tulsa Golden Hurricane football team|Tulsa]] 23, '''UCF 44''' |- |} ==The "Bounce House"== The stadium is also known as "The Bounce House"{{cite news|title=UCF continues to study why its football stadium bounces |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2008-03-08/news/stadium08_1_zombie-stadium-ucf |newspaper=Orlando Sentinel |accessdate=December 28, 2013 |date=March 8, 2008}}{{cite web|title=Bright House Networks Stadium |url=http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/bright-house-networks-stadium-s388/ |publisher=Stadium Journey |accessdate=December 28, 2013 |year=2012}}{{cite web |title=UCF Stadium Bounce House |url=http://www.wctv.tv/news/APNews/headlines/26205499.html |publisher=WCTV |accessdate=December 28, 2013 |date=August 2, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230233128/http://www.wctv.tv/news/APNews/headlines/26205499.html |archivedate=December 30, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|title=The Miami Hurricanes Will Beat UCF If...|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/272813-the-miami-hurricanes-will-beat-ucf-if|work=Bleacher Report|date=October 16, 2009|accessdate=December 19, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091017084342/http://bleacherreport.com/articles/272813-the-miami-hurricanes-will-beat-ucf-if|archivedate=October 17, 2009|df=mdy-all}} because the stadium vibrates and shakes when fans jump in unison, most notably when [[Zombie Nation (artist)|Zombie Nation]]'s song "[[Kernkraft 400]]" is played.{{cite news |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2007-11-30/news/stadium30_1_stadium-ucf-louie |title=Jumpy Fans Worry UCF |work=Orlando Sentinel|date=November 30, 2007 |accessdate=November 30, 2007}} While many fans like this feature, some are uneasy with the bouncing. Stadium officials claimed the stadium was structurally sound, and an independent contractor confirmed that the bouncing will not damage the stadium and shorten its expected 50–year useful life. Still, a project was begun prior to the 2008 season to reinforce the stadium superstructure and mitigate the bouncing effect.{{cite news|title=UCF to Take Bounce Out of Stadium|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2008-08-02/news/bounce02_1_stadium-fans-williams-brice|first=Luis|last=Zaragoza|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=August 2, 2009|accessdate=August 25, 2008}} While the bouncing has been greatly reduced by the stadium reinforcements, it is still noticeable - sometimes enough to shake TV cameras during televised games. For the [[2010 Conference USA Football Championship Game]], [[ESPN College Football|ESPN]] set up a camera position outside of the stadium to eliminate camera bounce caused by fans.{{cite web |title=C-USA Football Championship Blog|url=http://conferenceusa.cstv.com/ot/10-m-footbl-blog.html|work=Conference USA|date=December 2008|accessdate=January 1, 2011}} ==See also== {{Portal|Florida|College football}} *[[UCF Knights]] *[[Greater Orlando]] *[[History of the University of Central Florida]] *[[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist|35em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Official website}} {{S-start-collapsible|header={{S-sta|et}}}} {{Succession box | title = Home of the

[[MEAC/SWAC Challenge]] | years = 2014 | before = [[Orlando Citrus Bowl Stadium|Citrus Bowl]] | after = [[Orlando Citrus Bowl Stadium|Citrus Bowl]] }} {{End}} {{UCF Knights football navbox}} {{University of Central Florida}} {{American Athletic Conference football venue navbox}} {{American Athletic Conference Championship Game navbox}} {{Florida college football venues}} {{Metro Orlando}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:UCF Knights football]] [[Category:Sports venues in Orlando, Florida]] [[Category:American football venues in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2007]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Florida]] [[Category:Orlando Apollos]]

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Stadionul Venus | nickname = | image = | location = [[Bucharest]], [[Romania]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | opened = 11 October 1931 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = 1953 | owner = | operator = | surface = [[Grass]], [[Clay]] | Constructor = | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | nicknames = | tenants = [[Venus București]] (1928–1949)
[[Romania national football team|Romania]] (1939)
[[FC Steaua București|Steaua București]] (1947) | seating_capacity = 15,000 | dimensions = }} '''Venus Stadium''' was a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Bucharest]]. It was the home ground of [[Venus Bucharest]]. It held 15,000 people. Venus arena was inaugurated in 1931 as a field dedicated only to football. One of the oldest and most truthful leaders of the club, Alexandru Eladescu, sold a forest, private property, to obtain the necessary money to build the stadium. It held five [[Romanian Cup]] finals and one [[Romania national football team|Romania]] match on May 18, 1939, against [[Latvia national football team|Latvia]] finished 4-0. After the communist authorities came to power in Romania the club was dissolved and the arena demolished. It was situated where ''Parcul Operei'' is today. {{Football venues in Romania}} {{FC Steaua București}} {{Portal|Romanian football}} {{coord|44.436206|N|26.076629|E|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Venus, Stadionul}} [[Category:1931 establishments in Romania]] [[Category:FC Steaua București]] [[Category:Defunct football venues in Romania]] [[Category:Demolished buildings and structures in Bucharest]] [[Category:Greater Romania]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1931]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 1953]] [[Category:1953 disestablishments in Romania]] {{Romania-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} [[File:Helmut Haller - 1960s - Juventus FC.jpg|thumb|[[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] first popularised the star in 1958.<ref name=FIFA/>]]
In [[football]], some national and club sides include one or more [[Star (polygon)|stars]] as part of (or beside) the [[badge]] (often referred to as a "[[crest (sports)|crest]]") appearing on their shirt, to represent important trophies the team has previously won. Often this is a unilateral decision by a team itself, rather than a specific privilege earned or sanctioned by any governing body and as such, the relevance of these stars on a club's shirt is somewhat tenuous.
==Standardised significance==
===Club=== [[File:Scudetto.svg|thumb|upright|left|The ''scudetto'' (Italian for "little shield") was the source of inspiration for the adding of stars.]]
The first team in association football history to adopt a star was [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], who added one above their badge in 1958 to represent their tenth Italian Football Championship and [[Serie A]] title, at the time, the new national record.<ref name=FIFA>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/clubworldcup/japan2007/news/newsid=687173/index.html|title=FIFA awards special 'Club World Champion' badge to AC Milan|publisher=Fédération Internationale de Football Association|date=7 February 2008|accessdate=15 December 2014}}</ref> This was an extension of the existing convention by which the reigning champions are entitled to display the [[scudetto]] on their shirts for the following season. The star was later formally adopted by some organisations as a symbol for ten titles, and the ratio of one star for ten titles has become the "most common" arrangement.<ref name = "Talksport FC Bayern">{{cite news|title=Why Bayern Munich have only four stars on their shirt|work=talkSPORT|publisher=UTV Media|date=11 March 2014|accessdate=17 June 2016|url=http://talksport.com/football/why-bayern-munich-have-only-four-stars-their-shirt-14031183047}}</ref>
Juventus unofficially won their 30th league title in [[2011–12 Serie A|2011–12]], but a dispute with the [[Italian Football Federation]], who stripped Juventus of their 2004–05 and 2005–06 titles due to their involvement in a [[2006 Italian football scandal]], left their official total at 28. However, they elected to wear no stars at all the [[2012–13 Serie A|following season]].<ref>{{cite news|date=11 July 2012|title=Juventus reveal star-less shirts|work=football-italia.net|publisher=Football Italia|accessdate=16 June 2016|url=http://www.football-italia.net/21026/juventus-reveal-star-less-shirts}}</ref> Juventus won their 30th title in [[2013–14 Serie A|2013–14]] and thus earned the right to wear their third star, however, club president [[Andrea Agnelli]] stated that the club suspended the use of the stars until another team wins their 20th championship, thus having the right to wear two stars, "to emphasise Juventus' superiority".<ref name="Gladwell">{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/italian-serie-a/story/1811729/juventus-wont-add-star-to-badge-for-30th-title |date=6 May 2014 |accessdate=18 October 2014 |title=Juventus won't add 3rd star to badge |first=Ben |last=Gladwell |publisher=[[ESPN FC]]}}</ref> However, for the [[2015–16 Serie A|2015–16 season]], Juventus reintroduced the stars and added the third star to their jersey as well with new kit manufacturers [[Adidas]].<ref name=reintroduced>{{cite web|url=http://www.blackwhitereadallover.com/2015/7/1/8875999/juventus-2015-16-kits-adidas|title=Juventus' new 2015-16 adidas jerseys have officially arrived|publisher=SBNation|author=Danny Penza|date=1 July 2015|accessdate=14 April 2016}}</ref>
In Scotland, [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] displayed five stars above the badge on their shirts in 2003 to symbolise their 50 league titles. [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] have one star above their badge to represent their triumph in the 1967 European Cup. Aberdeen displayed two stars to commemorate their 1980s wins in the [[European Cup Winners' Cup]] and [[European Super Cup]].<ref>{{cite web| url=https://talksport.com/stars-and-gripes-clubs-ridiculous-symbols-their-shirts-including-man-united-liverpool-ipswich-and#DDCGzt4MkjTPM23d.99| title=Stars and gripes: clubs with ridiculous symbols on their shirts, including Man United, Liverpool, Ipswich and Huddersfield| first=Craig| last=Bloomfield| website=talksport.com| date=14 June 2011| access-date=1 November 2017}}</ref> [[File:Barrie McKay 2015.jpg|thumb|[[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] wear 5 stars to represent the 50 league championships they have amassed.]]
[[Football in Germany]] has two official star systems operating in parallel. In 2004, the DFL, which governs the [[Bundesliga]] (the top two divisions), introduced ''[[Bundesliga#Verdiente Meistervereine|Verdiente Meistervereine]]'' (roughly "distinguished champion clubs"). This has a sliding scale of 1, 2, 3, and 4 stars for 3, 5, 10, and 20 titles.<ref name="stuttgart-bundesliga"> {{cite web |url=http://www.bundesliga.de/de/liga/news/2006/index.php?f=61620.php |language=German |date=19 May 2007 |accessdate=6 May 2008 |title=Stuttgart holt ersten Stern |trans-title=Stuttgart gets first star |publisher=[[Bundesliga]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070521042147/http://www.bundesliga.de/de/liga/news/2006/index.php?f=61620.php |archivedate =21 May 2007 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> It includes only Bundesliga titles, excluding titles from before the formation of the Bundesliga in 1963, and from the [[DDR-Oberliga|former East German League]]. [[Berliner FC Dynamo|Dynamo Berlin]] (playing in [[NOFV-Oberliga Nord|the fourth level]]) unilaterally began wearing three unapproved stars for its East German titles.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,1581269,00.html |title=East Germany's Star Quality in Question |date=13 May 2005 |accessdate=6 May 2008 |publisher=dw-world.de |first=John |last=Kluempers}} </ref> In November 2005, the [[German Football Association|DFB]], which governs non-Bundesliga football, allowed former champions playing outside the Bundesliga to display a single star inscribed with the number of titles.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.dfb.de/fileadmin/Assets/pdf/durchfuehrungsbestimmung.pdf|title=Durchführungsbestimmungen|trans-title=Clothing instructions|page=54|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408212148/https://www.dfb.de/fileadmin/Assets/pdf/durchfuehrungsbestimmung.pdf|archivedate=8 April 2008|deadurl=yes|work=dfb.de|publisher=German Football Association|language=German}}</ref> In 2007, Dynamo Berlin switched to a single approved star inscribed with the number 10. [[SpVgg Greuther Fürth|Greuther Fürth]] retains three silver stars on its club badge, but not on its shirts.
[[Major League Soccer]]'s previously informal system, one star per [[MLS Cup]] title, was standardised in 2006, with the defending champions wearing the [[MLS Cup#Scudetto|MLS Scudetto]], like the [[Serie A]] system, for one season before adding a new star. Starting in 2012, the Scudetto was replaced with a single gold star worn by reigning champions above any other silver championship stars. In 2016, this system changed again in recognition of the [[LA Galaxy]]'s fifth championship title: champion clubs during their title defence will wear a large gold star (featuring the year of the league win) above other smaller stars set in silver; clubs with five championships (presently only the Galaxy) will wear one gold star; and teams with one-to-four MLS Cup wins will wear one silver star for each victory.<ref>{{cite news|title=Here's what's changing about championship stars on MLS jerseys this year|date=4 February 2016|first=Arielle|last=Castillo|work=mlssoccer.com|publisher=Major League Soccer|accessdate=16 June 2016|url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2016/02/04/here-s-what-s-changing-about-championship-stars-mls-jerseys-year}}</ref> In Australia, they also use a system based around different coloured stars for different trophy wins: Australian winners of the [[AFC Champions League]] will wear a gold star inscribed with the number of wins, while [[A-League]] and [[W-League (Australia)|W-League]] victory is recognised with a silver star similarly embossed; reigning league or [[FFA Cup]] champions will also wear a gold competition emblem in the season following the championship.<ref name = "Australia">{{Cite news|work=fourfourtwo.com/au|publisher=FourFourTwo Australia|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/au/news/ffa-approves-strip-stars-champion-clubs#|accessdate=16 June 2016|title=FFA approves strip stars for champion clubs|date=15 January 2015}}</ref>
In Norway a team will display a star for every 10 titles in [[Tippeligaen]]. [[Rosenborg BK|Rosenborg]] is the only team with more than 10 titles. Since 2006, all Swedish football clubs that have won ten or more [[Swedish football champions|Swedish championships]] have added a star above their badge. [[Malmö FF]] added a second star following its 20th championship title win in 2017. The same system has applied in the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Eredivisie]] from the [[Eredivisie 2007–08|2007–08 season]] onwards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eredivisie.nl/subpage.aspx?l1=1637&subaction=details&newsid=186&type=0|publisher=[[Eredivisie]]|title=Kampioenssterren wijzen op historische roem|trans-title=Champions' stars show past glories|date=11 May 2007|accessdate=16 May 2007|language=Dutch|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024161254/http://www.eredivisie.nl/subpage.aspx?l1=1637&subaction=details&newsid=186&type=0|archivedate=24 October 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This innovation was suggested by [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]], after the club won its twentieth title in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.psv.nl/web/show/id=58980/contentid=20826 |title=Reigning champions PSV display two stars on their shirts |quote="We have conceived a plan to not only introduce these two stars on the championship badge, but on the shirts as well", explained PSV Manager Match Organisation Ron Verkerk. "We have made a proposal to the KNVB, the Royal Dutch Football Association and the ECV, the Association of Eredivisie clubs, and they have both independently responded enthusiastically." |publisher=[[PSV Eindhoven]] |date=2 May 2007 |accessdate=16 May 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070504183523/http://english.psv.nl/web/show/id%3D58980/contentid%3D20826 |archivedate=4 May 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] currently have the right to wear three stars since they have won the league more than 30 times. PSV have the right to wear two stars with their 21 league titles, while [[Feyenoord]] and [[HVV Den Haag]] can add one for their 15 and 10 titles, respectively. HVV won all titles before 1915 and is currently playing in the fourth level of the Dutch league system. In Malta, [[Floriana F.C.|Floriana]], [[Valletta F.C.|Valletta]] and [[Sliema Wanderers F.C.|Sliema Wanderers]] boast 2 Golden Stars on their badges having won 25, 20 and 26 titles, respectively, while [[Hibernians F.C.|Hibernians]] have one star thanks to their 10 titles. No other team in the Maltese League has the golden star on their badge. {{double image|left|Tampa Bay Rowdies logo (one gold star).svg|100|Tampa Bay Rowdies logo (two green stars).svg|100|The [[Tampa Bay Rowdies]] added a star in recognition of a title won by a [[Tampa Bay Rowdies (1975–93)|former club with the same name]]. They have since added another star after the new club won a league championship of its own.||Rowdies logo used from 2011-2013|Rowdies logo used since 2013|}}
Occasionally, stars are added to badges of successor or phoenix clubs for the achievements of defunct predecessors. An example of this is the [[Tampa Bay Rowdies]]. They added a star to represent the [[Soccer Bowl]], the championship of the [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|original NASL]], won by the [[Tampa Bay Rowdies (1975–93)|original Tampa Bay Rowdies]] in [[Soccer Bowl '75|1975]]. The club has since added a second star, after the new club won the [[Soccer Bowl 2012|2012]] edition of the resurrected Soccer Bowl in the [[North American Soccer League|new NASL]].<ref name="Rowdies" /> This approach is atypical: neither the [[Montreal Impact]] nor the [[Seattle Sounders FC]] franchises retained the stars worn by the old clubs when they joined the MLS.<ref group="nb">The [[Seattle Sounders (1994–2008)|Seattle Sounders]] that played from 1994 to 2008 wore four stars, while the former [[Montreal Impact (1992–2011)|Montreal Impact]] team wore three stars at the time of their move.</ref> In the case of the Impact, the new team paid tribute to the former team's first title through the stripes on their badge.<ref name = "Impact MLS">{{cite news|title=Montreal Impact Logo|work=sportslogos.net|publisher=Chris Creamer's Sports Logos Page|url=http://www.sportslogos.net/logos/view/ugsnhv0oteegw8sjs3e4wivvg/Montreal_Impact/2012/Primary_Logo|accessdate=1 September 2014|date=7 August 2011}}</ref>
As well as predecessor clubs, victories in the national leagues of defunct countries have also been represented by stars. [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]] have two stars, commemorating championships won in the [[Soviet Union football league system|Soviet]] and [[Ukrainian football league system]]s. The same is true of [[Belgrade]] clubs [[FK Partizan|Partizan]] and [[Red Star Belgrade|Red Star]] who have won titles in [[Yugoslav First League|Yugoslavia]], [[First League of Serbia and Montenegro|Serbia and Montenegro]] and present-day [[Serbian SuperLiga|Serbia]], while [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]]'s stars refer to their [[Soviet Top League]] and [[Russian Football Premier League]] achievements.
The star has given rise to a byword to winning trophies. Examples of this include when [[Fawaz Al-Hasawi]], owner of [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]], was quoted as saying "maybe [Nottingham Forest] will have a third star",<ref>{{cite news|title=Fawaz Al Hasawi aiming to guide Nottingham Forest back to Europe|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11727/8557582/fawaz-al-hasawi-aiming-to-guide-nottingham-forest-back-to-europe|work=Sky Sports|publisher=British Sky Broadcasting|date=11 March 2013|accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> and [[France national football team|France]] international [[Paul Pogba]]'s comments in the days before the [[2018 FIFA World Cup Final]]: "[[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] do not have stars – they want one. They have done very well and they want the victory, like us. But I do not have a star. It’s on the shirt, but I did not win it. We want to go looking for it like all players."<ref>{{cite news|title=Paul Pogba eager to earn his own World Cup star on France shirt|date=12 July 2018|accessdate=12 July 2018|work=Belfast Telegraph|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/paul-pogba-eager-to-earn-his-own-world-cup-star-on-france-shirt-37110100.html}}</ref>
===International=== [[File:Nike Brazil national football team home jersey.JPG|thumb|upright|The first international team to add stars was [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]]. Their badge now features five stars.]]
[[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] had two stars above their badge in 1968. It was used briefly (friendly matches only) and then removed. After winning their third [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] in [[Football World Cup 1970|1970]], three stars was officially added and [[Italy national football team|Italy]] did likewise in [[Football World Cup 1982|1982]]. [[Germany national football team|Germany]] added three in 1996, one in each of the [[Flag of Germany|German flag]]'s colours. All world champions have since followed suit. Brazil, Italy, and Germany have since added more stars, after they won later tournaments (cf. [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]], [[2002 FIFA World Cup|2002]], [[2006 FIFA World Cup|2006]], [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]]), while France are the most recent nation to add a star, commemorating their [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018]] triumph less than an hour after victory in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup Final|Final]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Second star added to France's World Cup kit after Russia 2018 triumph over Croatia|work=CBS Sports|url=https://www.cbssports.com/soccer/world-cup/news/second-star-added-to-frances-world-cup-kit-after-russia-2018-triumph-over-croatia/|date=15 July 2018|first1=Roger|last1=Gonzalez|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref>
[[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] display four stars, regarding their triumphs in the [[Football at the 1924 Summer Olympics|1924]] and [[1928 Summer Olympics|1928 Olympics]] as equivalent to their later World Cup wins, as there was no World Cup at the time. ''[[Eurosport]]'' claim that FIFA only recognises the two World Cup wins,<ref>{{cite news|title=The 10 most infamous kits in World Cup history|work=uk.eurosport.yahoo.com|publisher=Eurosport|date=4 June 2014|url=https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/blogs/the-rio-report/world-cup-kits-10-interesting-anecdotes-074914947.html|accessdate=3 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103032341/https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/blogs/the-rio-report/world-cup-kits-10-interesting-anecdotes-074914947.html|archivedate=3 November 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> while the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' state that "when FIFA revised its constitution in 1950, they formally recognised that Uruguay were four-time world champions".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/worldcup2014/article-2664274/Luis-Suarezs-Uruguay-won-World-Cup-twice-four-gold-stars-crest.html|title=Luis Suarez's Uruguay have won the World Cup twice, so why do they have four gold stars above their crest?|first=Adam|last=Shergold|date=21 June 2014|accessdate=3 November 2014|work=Daily Mail}}</ref>
In the equipment regulations for FIFA competitions, section 16.1 states " Those Member Associations that have won one or more of the previous editions of the FIFA World Cup™ or the FIFA Women’s World Cup™ may display on the Playing Equipment used by their first men’s or women’s representative teams a five-pointed star, or other symbol as instructed by FIFA, per edition of the FIFA World Cup™ (men’s shirt) or FIFA Women’s World Cup™ (women’s shirt) won by the Member Association"<ref name="fifa-equipment-regs"> {{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/51/54/30/equipment_reg_26032010_en.pdf |title=Equipment Regulations: Regulations Governing the Sports Equipment at FIFA Competitions |date=18 October 2003 |publisher=FIFA |pages=39, §16.1 |accessdate=13 July 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215101101/http://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/51/54/30/equipment_reg_26032010_en.pdf |archivedate=15 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }}.</ref> The form of symbol is now specified, the accompanying illustrative example depicts a gold star.<ref name="fifa-equipment-regs"/>
==Ad hoc adoptions== More recently, club teams have added stars either upon winning a landmark trophy, or in response to a [[Major football rivalries|rival team]]'s having added stars. In the [[Liga I|Romanian first league]], [[FC Steaua Bucureşti|Steaua]] uses 2 stars above their badge since they won their 20th title. Since then [[FC Dinamo Bucureşti|Dinamo]] added a star for the 18 championships they won. [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] sported a star in their [[UEFA Champions League]] matches on their special European home kit between [[1997–98 UEFA Champions League|1997]] and [[1998–99 UEFA Champions League|1999]].<ref name = "Talksport">{{cite news|title=Stars and gripes: clubs with ridiculous symbols on their shirts, including Man United, Liverpool, Ipswich and Huddersfield|first=Craig|last=Bloomfield|date=14 June 2011|url=http://talksport.com/stars-and-gripes-clubs-ridiculous-symbols-their-shirts-including-man-united-liverpool-ipswich-and|accessdate=2 November 2014|work=Talksport|publisher=UTV Media}}</ref> To celebrate their second victory [[1999 UEFA Champions League Final|that year]], they added an extra star to that kit for the [[1999–2000 UEFA Champions League|1999–00]] season.<ref name="Talksport" /> [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] likewise wore four stars in [[2001–02 UEFA Champions League|2001–02]], their first campaign in the competition since the [[Heysel Stadium disaster]] in 1985.<ref name="Talksport" /> They wore five stars in the competition in [[2005–06 UEFA Champions League|2005–06]] after their fifth victory. Instead of stars, UEFA introduced a ''[[European Champion Clubs' Cup#Multiple-winner badge|multiple winner badge]]'' in 2000–01 season, currently worn by five teams who have won the Champions League either five times or more in total, or three times in a row. [[File:Jonny Wilkinson September 2013 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|left|Using stars to represent trophy wins has spread to other sports: [[rugby union]] club [[RC Toulonnais|Toulon]] are an example of this.]]
Occasionally, stars are temporarily added for one season, usually to commemorative kits to celebrate the anniversary of a particular event in the club's history. [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] sported two stars on their 2006–07 shirt, for the club's 125th anniversary, to celebrate their two league titles in 1921 and 1960.<ref name="Talksport" /> Likewise [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] in 2009–10, also for their 125th anniversary, commemorating their 1900 and 1903 FA Cup triumphs; Bury have since revived the stars, from 2011–12, after a season's absence.<ref name = "Bury">{{cite news|url=http://historicalkits.co.uk/Bury/Bury.htm|title=Bury|work=historicalkits.co.uk|publisher=Historical Football Kits|first=Dave|last=Moor|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> Commemorating anniversaries in this way is not confined to English clubs: Peruvian side [[Club Universitario de Deportes|Universitario]] celebrated their 90th anniversary by adding 26 stars to their kits worn home<ref>{{cite news|title=Universitario 90th Anniversary Umbro Special Edition Home Shirt|date=14 September 2014|work=footballshirtculture.com|url=http://www.footballshirtculture.com/14/15-Kits/universitario-90th-anniversary-umbro-special-edition-home-shirt.html|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> and away.<ref>{{cite news|title=Universitario 90th Anniversary Umbro Special Edition Away Shirt|date=14 September 2014|work=footballshirtculture.com|url=http://www.footballshirtculture.com/14/15-Kits/universitario-90th-anniversary-umbro-special-edition-away-shirt.html|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref> This is not a practice limited to clubs, as in 2004, [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] wore a star on their shirts specially for [[UEFA Euro 2004|Euro 2004]], to commemorate their victory in the [[UEFA European Football Championship|competition]] in [[UEFA Euro 1992|1992]].
In [[women's football (soccer)|women's football]], the emerging ad hoc standard is to wear stars on the sleeve instead of above the badge. Two of the four teams that have won the [[FIFA Women's World Cup]] to date — [[Norway women's national football team|Norway]] and [[Germany women's national football team|Germany]] — use this practice, as did three-time Women's World Cup winners, the [[United States women's national soccer team|USA]], until moving the stars to the back collar in 2007. The United States has returned its two stars to above the badge on their new uniforms for the [[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup|2011 Women's World Cup]],<ref name = "USWNT">{{cite news|title=NIKE US WOMEN'S NATIONAL TEAM (USWNT) 2011 KIT|url=http://www.soccerbible.com/performance/football-apparel/2011/04/nike-us-women-s-national-team-uswnt-2011-kit/|date=5 April 2011|accessdate=1 September 2014|work=soccerbible.com}}</ref> and have added a third since their [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup]] championship.<ref name = "USWNT 3">{{cite news|title=Three Star Jerseys Unveiled During FOX Special|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2015/07/07/09/34/150707-wnt-fox-three-star-special|date=July 7, 2015|accessdate=May 20, 2016|work=ussoccer.com|publisher=United States Soccer Federation}}</ref>
The practice of using stars to signify major titles has spread to other football codes, and to unrelated sports. For example, in 2009, [[Meath GAA|Meath senior Gaelic football team]] began wearing seven stars on their jerseys, signifying their seven [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship]]s.<ref>https://www.pressreader.com/ireland/drogheda-independent/20090211/283527971711079</ref> In [[rugby union]], [[RC Toulonnais|Toulon]] added a star above its badge after winning the [[Heineken Cup]] in [[2013 Heineken Cup Final|2013]], added a second star immediately after winning the same competition in [[2014 Heineken Cup Final|2014]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espnscrum.com/france-top-14-2013-14/rugby/story/227527.html |title=Wilkinson's name stitched into Toulon shirts |publisher=''ESPN Scrum'' |date=31 May 2014 |accessdate=31 May 2014 |quote=Toulon's shirts [for the 2014 [[Top 14]] final] will also feature a second silver star above the club's crest, marking their back-to-back Heineken Cup titles.}}</ref> and a third after winning the inaugural [[European Rugby Champions Cup]] in [[2015 European Rugby Champions Cup Final|2015]]; English rugby union side [[Sale Sharks]] wear a gold star in tribute to their sole [[Premiership Rugby|Premiership]] title.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sale Sharks Samurai 2015/16 Home & Alternate Shirts|date=28 September 2015|accessdate=7 February 2018|work=rugbyshirtwatch.com|url=https://rugbyshirtwatch.com/2015/09/28/sale-sharks-samurai-201516-home-alternate-shirts/}}</ref> In [[basketball]], the [[Indiana Hoosiers men's basketball|men's team]] of [[Indiana University Bloomington]] added five stars to its shorts, representing its five [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship|NCAA championships]], for the [[2015 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|2015 NCAA tournament]], and made the stars at that location a permanent fixture for the [[2015–16 Indiana Hoosiers men's basketball team|2015–16 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/14067435/uni-watch-2015-16-college-basketball-season-preview-november-madness |title=Uni Watch 2015-16 college basketball season preview: November madness |first=Paul |last=Lukas |publisher=''[[ESPN.com]]'' |date=10 November 2015 |accessdate=10 November 2015}}</ref>
==List== Excluding the temporary stars, the following teams have chosen to add stars to their shirts: <!-- entries are listed 1. country sides before club sides 2. men's national sides before women's national teams (more men's sides, and "men" comes before "women" in the alphabet 3. clubs grouped by country alphabetically 4. number of stars 5. prestige of trophy 6. alphabetical -->
===National teams===

Uruguay are four time FIFA World Champions"].</ref> |-- |{{fb|ARG}} |World Cup |1978 |2 |Titles won in [[1978 FIFA World Cup|1978]] and [[1986 FIFA World Cup|1986]].
