Four stars were added in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Kit Bag: USL PRO 2013 Part 2|date=April 24, 2013|first=Ray|last=Stellhorn|url=http://www.recklesschallenge.net/the-kit-bag-usl-pro-2013-part-2/|work=recklesschallenge.net|accessdate=March 31, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402093418/http://www.recklesschallenge.net/the-kit-bag-usl-pro-2013-part-2/|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> |- |[[San Antonio Scorpions FC]] |{{USA}} |[[North American Soccer League]] championship |1 |Title won in [[Soccer Bowl 2014|2014]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sascorpions.com/news/detail/uuid/18rxogda2mugc1v8pt6nlqwezd/san-antonio-scorpions-are-nasl-champions#.VG552YvF_ec|title=THE SAN ANTONIO SCORPIONS ARE NASL CHAMPIONS!!|date=November 16, 2014|work=sascorpions.com|publisher=San Antonio Scorpions|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141121125643/http://www.sascorpions.com/news/detail/uuid/18rxogda2mugc1v8pt6nlqwezd/san-antonio-scorpions-are-nasl-champions#.Vz9jo77IHIU|archivedate=21 November 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> star added shortly afterwards.<ref>{{cite tweet |author= San Antonio Scorpions |user= SAScorpions|number= 535119316903931904 |date= November 19, 2014 |title= Shiny addition |access-date= May 20, 2016 }}</ref> |- |[[Cleveland City Stars]] |{{USA}} |[[USL Second Division]] championship |1 |Cleveland won the 2008 [[USL Second Division]] championship and moved into the [[USL First Division]] for 2009, along with the [[Austin Aztex]], to replace the departed [[Seattle Sounders (1994–2008)|Seattle Sounders]] and [[Atlanta Silverbacks]]. The team folded after the 2009 season. |- |[[Tulsa Roughnecks FC]] |{{USA}} |[[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|North American Soccer League]] championship |1 |The team, which began play in 2015 in the rebranded [[United Soccer League]], added a star to the back of their inaugural kit to represent the [[Tulsa Roughnecks (1978–84)|original Tulsa Roughnecks]]' sole Soccer Bowl success, when victory in [[Soccer Bowl '83]] resulted in them being crowned [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|NASL]] champions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uslsoccer.com/home/834007.html |title=Roughnecks Unveil Logo, Uniforms |publisher=United Soccer Leagues |work=uslsoccer.com |date=September 2, 2014 |accessdate=September 8, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006131544/http://www.uslsoccer.com/home/834007.html |archivedate=6 October 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> |- |[[Akron Zips men's soccer|Akron Zips]] |{{USA}} |[[NCAA]] [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] |1 |Represents [[2010 NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship]]. |- |[[Northern Kentucky Norse]] |{{USA}} |[[NCAA]] [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] |1 |Represents club's 2010 [[NCAA Division II]] [[NCAA Division II Men's Soccer Championship|national championship]]. ==Stars that do not signify particular titles== American club [[Philadelphia Union]] has 13 stars that represent the [[Thirteen Colonies|13 original colonies]] of the United States.<ref>{{cite news|title=CLUB HISTORY|url=http://www.philadelphiaunion.com/club/history|publisher=Philadelphia Union|work=philadelphiaunion.com|accessdate=2014-08-30}}</ref> Fellow [[Major League Soccer]] franchise [[Montreal Impact]] have four stars on their badge, which are symbolic of the nationalities of the peoples who founded the city of [[Montreal]].<ref name="Impact MLS" /> The four nations are regularly used in Montreal imagery, as the city [[flag of Montreal|flag]] and [[coat of arms of Montreal|coat of arms]] both reference them.
The badge of [[Club Atlético Peñarol|Peñarol]] of [[Uruguay]] has 11 stars for the 11 players.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://capenarol.com.uy/sitio/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=16&Itemid=44 |accessdate=2008-05-04 |publisher=[[Club Atlético Peñarol|C.A. Peñarol]] |title=Simbología Oficial — Imagen & Identidad Corporativa |language=Spanish |quote=once estrellas, que representan a los jugadores que se encuentran en el campo de juego |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080314094039/http://capenarol.com.uy/sitio/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=16&Itemid=44 |archivedate = 14 March 2008}}</ref>
The [[Manchester City F.C.#Club badge and colours|badge introduced by Manchester City]] in 1997 had three stars to give it a "more [[Continental Europe|continental]] feel".<ref>From the official 1997 press release at the badge's introduction; quoted in {{cite web |url=http://www.uit.no/mancity/club/history.html |title=Manchester City: OFFICIALS AND HISTORY |first=Svenn |last=Hanssen |accessdate=2007-01-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130223003841/http://www.uit.no/mancity/club/history.html |archivedate=23 February 2013 |df=dmy-all }}.</ref> The 3 stars do not represent titles or trophies. City brought in a new club badge in 2016 with no stars on it.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Manchester City|url=http://historicalkits.co.uk/Manchester_City/Manchester_City.htm|accessdate=16 June 2016|work=historicalkits.co.uk|publisher=Historical Football Kits|first=Dave|last=Moor}}</ref> [[Sivasspor]] of [[Turkey]] also has three stars on their badge. They do not represent any championships either.
[[Portsmouth F.C.]] has featured a star (of various designs) in its badge since 1913. The star does not represent trophies or titles won, instead, the Portsmouth badge was based upon symbols found in the official coat of arms owned by [[Portsmouth City Council]].
For the 2002–03 season, the badge of Greek club [[Panathinaikos F.C.]] had 3 stars. One gold representing the team's partaking in the [[1971 European Cup Final]], and 2 white stars representing the team's participation at the 1985 European Cup semi-finals and the 1996 [[UEFA Champions League]] semi-finals respectively. Because none of these stars represent titles or trophies, opposition fans in Greece mocked this.
[[Johor Darul Takzim F.C.]] has 3 stars above its badge, for each time the club changed its name; from PKENJ to Johor and finally Johor Darul Takzim.{{citation needed|date=August 2014}}
Following the crash of [[LaMia Flight 2933]], Brazilian club [[Associação Chapecoense de Futebol|Chapecoense]] incorporated a star into its badge as a tribute to those who perished in the incident.<ref name="chape" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Tim Noakes |image = Dr. Tim Noakes at West Point 13 Nov 09.JPG |image_size = 200px |caption = Tim Noakes at [[United States Military Academy|West Point]] in 2009 |birth_name = Timothy David Noakes |birth_date = 1949 |birth_place = [[Harare|Salisbury]], [[Southern Rhodesia]]
(today Harare, Zimbabwe) |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = South African |religion = |ethnicity = |fields = [[Exercise physiology]] |workplaces = [[University of Cape Town]] |alma_mater = [[University of Cape Town]]
[[Diocesan College]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = [[Central governor|Central Governor Theory of Fatigue]]
[[Hyponatremia]] research
The "Noakes Diet" |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |awards = *{{Timeline-event|date=2002 |event= Doctor of Science [[University of Cape Town|(UCT)]]}} *{{Timeline-event|date=2002 |event= International Cannes Grand Prix Award}} *{{Timeline-event|date=2008 |event= [[Order of Mapungubwe|Order of Mapungubwe (Silver)]]}} *{{Timeline-event|date=2011 |event= [[Honorary degree|Honorary doctorate]], [[Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam]]}} *{{Timeline-event|date=2012 |event= Lifetime Achievement Award [[National Research Foundation of South Africa|(South Africa's NRF)]]}} *{{Timeline-event|date=2014 |event= South Africa Medal (gold) [[Southern Africa Association for the Advancement of Science|(S2A3)]]}} |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Timothy David Noakes''' (born 1949) is a [[South Africa]]n scientist, and an emeritus professor in the Division of Exercise Science and Sports Medicine at the [[University of Cape Town]]. He is also a member of the [[National Research Foundation of South Africa]], who list him as one of their highest-rated members.{{Cite web|url = https://www.uct.ac.za/about/honours/nrfratings/|title = University of Cape Town|date = 2015|accessdate = 28 January 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150110062539/http://www.uct.ac.za/about/honours/nrfratings/|archivedate = 10 January 2015|df = }} He has run more than 70 [[marathon]]s and [[ultramarathon]]s,{{cite web |url=http://runneracademy.com/ra024-tim-noakes/ |title=RA024 Dr. Tim Noakes: A Lifetime of Running and Research}} and is the author of several books on exercise and diet. He is known for his support of a [[low-carbohydrate diet|low-carbohydrate, high-fat (LCHF) diet]], as set out in his books ''The Real Meal Revolution'' and ''Lore of Nutrition: Challenging Conventional Dietary Beliefs''. ==Background== Noakes was born in [[Harare|Salisbury]], [[Southern Rhodesia]] (today Harare, Zimbabwe) in 1949 and moved to South Africa at the age of five.{{cite web|url=http://www.health24.com/fitness/Specific_Sports/16-2175-2181-2277,50688.asp|title=How Tim Noakes wants you to train|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614091149/http://www.health24.com/fitness/Specific_Sports/16-2175-2181-2277,50688.asp|archivedate=14 June 2011|df=}} His father had arrived in what was then Southern Rhodesia in 1946, establishing a successful tobacco exporting company that he sold in 1954.{{cite web | title = Dear Editor: Tim Noakes replies | url = http://www.noseweek.co.za/article/186/Dear-Editor| publisher= Noseweek| volume = 31 | accessdate = 6 June 2014}} As a young boy his main sporting interest was cricket. Noakes attended Monterey Preparatory School in [[Constantia, Cape Town]]. One year was spent as a foreign exchange student at [[Huntington Park High School]] in [[Huntington Park, California]]. Prep school was followed by [[Diocesan College]]. He has earned an [[MBChB]] (1974), [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] (1981), and [[DSc|DSc (Med)]] (2002). ==Research== In 1980 Noakes was tasked to start a sports science course at the [[University of Cape Town]]. Noakes went on to head the [[Medical Research Council (UK)|Medical Research Council]]-funded Bioenergetics of Exercise Research Unit, which was later changed to the MRC/UCT Research Unit for Exercise Science and Sports Medicine.[http://web.uct.ac.za/depts/essm/ MRC/UCT Research Unit for Exercise Science and Sports Medicine] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121224222317/http://web.uct.ac.za/depts/essm/ |date=24 December 2012 }} In the early 1990s Noakes co-founded the Sports Science Institute of South Africa,[http://www.ssisa.com/ Sports Science Institute of South Africa] with former South African rugby player [[Morne du Plessis]]. His unit's physiological research has produced over 370 scientific articles since 1996. He is a leading researcher on the condition now known as [[Exercise-associated hyponatremia]] (EAH).{{cite journal|last=Speedy|first=DB|author2=Noakes TD |author3=Schneider C |title=Exercise-associated Hyponatremia: A review.|journal=Emerg Med (Fremantle)|year=2001|volume=13|pages=17–27|url=http://cjasn.asnjournals.org/content/2/1/151.full|accessdate=6 January 2014|doi=10.1046/j.1442-2026.2001.00173.x}} He first recognized this condition in a female runner during the 1984 [[Comrades Marathon]], and published his findings in 1985 in the journal ''Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise''. Noakes hosted the 1st International Exercise-Associated Hyponatremia Consensus Development Conference in [[Cape Town]] in May 2005. Noakes is also known for renewing and elaborating the idea first proposed by the 1922 [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] winner [[Archibald Hill]] that a [[central governor]] regulates exercise to protect body [[Human homeostasis|homeostasis]].{{Cite journal | last1 = St Clair Gibson | first1 = A. | last2 = Baden | first2 = D. A. | last3 = Lambert | first3 = M. I. | last4 = Lambert | first4 = E. V. | last5 = Harley | first5 = Y. X. | last6 = Hampson | first6 = D. | last7 = Russell | first7 = V. A. | last8 = Noakes | first8 = T. D. | title = The conscious perception of the sensation of fatigue | journal = Sports Medicine | volume = 33 | issue = 3 | pages = 167–176 | year = 2003 | pmid = 12656638 | doi=10.2165/00007256-200333030-00001 }}{{Cite journal | last1 = Noakes | first1 = T. D. | last2 = St Clair Gibson | first2 = A. | last3 = Lambert | first3 = E. V. | doi = 10.1136/bjsm.2003.010330 | title = From catastrophe to complexity: A novel model of integrative central neural regulation of effort and fatigue during exercise in humans: Summary and conclusions | journal = British Journal of Sports Medicine | volume = 39 | issue = 2 | pages = 120–124 | year = 2005 | pmid = 15665213 | pmc =1725112 }}{{Cite journal | last1 = Noakes | first1 = T. D. | last2 = Peltonen | first2 = J. E. | last3 = Rusko | first3 = H. K. | title = Evidence that a central governor regulates exercise performance during acute hypoxia and hyperoxia | journal = The Journal of Experimental Biology | volume = 204 | issue = Pt 18 | pages = 3225–3234 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11581338 }}{{Cite journal | last1 = St Clair Gibson | first1 = A. | last2 = Lambert | first2 = M. L. | last3 = Noakes | first3 = T. D. | title = Neural control of force output during maximal and submaximal exercise | journal = Sports Medicine | volume = 31 | issue = 9 | pages = 637–650 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11508520 | doi=10.2165/00007256-200131090-00001 }} In 2005 he undertook a series of pioneering experiments in the Arctic and Antarctic on South African (British-born) swimmer [[Lewis Gordon Pugh]] to understand the full range of human capability in extreme cold. He discovered that Pugh had the ability to raise his core body temperature before entering the water in anticipation of the cold and coined the phrase 'anticipatory thermo-genesis' to describe it. In 2007, Noakes was the expedition doctor for Pugh’s one kilometer swim at the [[Geographic North Pole]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} ==Bibliography== Noakes has written several books detailing his research in sports science and nutrition. A selected bibliography is given below. *''Lore of Running'' (1986) Noakes, Tim. 2003. ''The Lore of Running.'' (4th edition) [[Oxford University Press]] {{ISBN|0-87322-959-2}} *''Running Injuries: How to Prevent and Overcome Them'' (1990) *''Bob Woolmer's Art and Science of Cricket'' (2008) *''Challenging Beliefs: Memoirs of a Career'' (2012) *''Waterlogged: The Serious Problem of Overhydration in Endurance Sports'' (2012) *''The Real Meal Revolution'' (2014) *''Raising Superheroes'' (2015) *''Lore of Nutrition: Challenging Conventional Dietary Beliefs'', with Marika Sboros (2017) ==Controversy== The [[low-carbohydrate diet|low-carbohydrate, high-fat diet]], often referred to as the "Tim Noakes", "[[William Banting|Banting]]" or LCHF diet in South Africa, has gained considerable popularity in the country since 2010,{{cite web |url= http://www.health24.com/Diet-and-nutrition/Healthy-foods/Tim-Noakes-Diet-The-Paleo-Diet-is-it-worth-the-switch-20140218|title=Paleo diet - is it worth the switch?|author= |date=19 February 2014 |website=health24.com |publisher= |accessdate=16 July 2014}} but has also drawn a significant amount of criticism. Noakes has claimed, among others{{clarification needed|date=April 2018}}, that high blood cholesterol is not a contributing factor to heart disease,{{cite web |url= http://www.health24.com/Medical/Heart/Foods-diet-and-your-heart/Experts-warn-against-Noakes-diet-20130212|title=Experts warn against Noakes diet|author= |date=25 February 2014 |website=health24.com |publisher= |accessdate=16 July 2014}} and he has been criticized for publishing a series of case reports as a scientific paper.{{cite web |url=http://www.news24.com/Archives/City-Press/Tim-Noakes-weight-loss-paper-sparks-row-20150429|title=Tim Noakes’ weight-loss paper sparks row|author= |date=27 October 2013 |website=news24.com |publisher=CityPress |accessdate=24 July 2015}} In an open letter{{cite web|last1=De Villiers|first1=W.|last2=Mayosi|first2=B.|last3=Opie|first3=L.|last4=Senekal|first4=M.|title=Noakes diet and health implications: an open letter to the Cape Times|url=http://www.health.uct.ac.za/news/noakes-diet-and-health-implications-open-letter-cape-times|website=Faculty of Health Sciences|publisher=University of Cape Town|accessdate=17 February 2016}} (dated 22 August 2014) to the [[Cape Times]], fellow [[University of Cape Town|University of Cape Town (UCT)]] academics argued against Noakes's dietary ideas. The letter was signed by Wim de Villiers (Dean, Faculty of Health Sciences), [[Bongani Mayosi]] (Head, Department of Medicine), Lionel Opie (Hatter Institute of Cardiology, Department of Medicine) and Marjanne Senekal (Head, Division of Human Nutrition). The letter was copied to Noakes and several others. In the letter the academics expressed, among others, "...serious concern that Professor Timothy Noakes, a colleague respected for his research in sports science, is aggressively promoting this diet as a ‘revolution’, making outrageous unproven claims about disease prevention, and maligning the integrity and credibility of peers who criticise his diet for being evidence-deficient and not conforming to the tenets of good and responsible science. This goes against the University of Cape Town’s commitment to academic freedom as the prerequisite to fostering responsible and respectful intellectual debate and free enquiry." Noakes, also in the form of an open letter to the [[Cape Times]], responded to the criticism by his colleagues.{{cite news|last1=Sboros|first1=M.|title=Tim Noakes – backlash as UCT academics say he’s a danger to the public|url=http://www.biznews.com/health/2014/08/25/tim-noakes-backlash-uct-academics-say-hes-danger-public/|accessdate=17 February 2016|publisher=BizNews.com|date=25 August 2014}} He accused the [[University of Cape Town|UCT]] Faculty of Health Sciences of consistently misrepresenting his public message "...which is simply the following: a high carbohydrate diet is detrimental to the health of persons with [[insulin resistance]] whereas [[Low-carbohydrate diet|carbohydrate restriction]] in this group can be profoundly beneficial as it can reverse [[obesity]] and in some cases [[Diabetes mellitus type 2|Type 2 diabetes mellitus]], the two conditions that will ultimately bankrupt South African medical services unless we take appropriate preventive actions." He described the denial by the [[University of Cape Town|UCT]] Faculty of Health Sciences of peer-reviewed evidence in support of his views as "a classic example of [[cognitive dissonance]].” In February 2014 Claire Julsing-Strydom, President of the Association for Dietetics in South Africa (ADSA), reported Noakes to the Health Professions Council of South Africa (HPCSA) for advising a mother on Twitter that she should wean her child onto low-carbohydrate high-fat foods, which he described as real foods. "By implication I was saying that the child should not be weaned onto the traditional high sugar, high carbohydrate processed cereals."{{cite web |url=http://www.health24.com/Diet-and-nutrition/Healthy-foods/Tim-Noakes-to-face-inquiry-over-Banting-tweet-20150421|title=Tim Noakes to face inquiry over 'Banting' tweet|author= |date=6 May 2015 |website=health24.com |publisher=Health24 |accessdate=24 July 2015}} In response to the complaint, the Professional Conduct Committee of the HPCSA, chaired by Advocate Joan Adams, set up a hearing into the allegation of unprofessional conduct against Noakes. The hearing was scheduled for 4 June 2015, but following complaints from Noakes's legal team that the Committee was not properly constituted in accordance with the applicable regulations and the provisions of the Health Professions Act, its commencement was delayed until November 2015.{{cite news|last1=Sboros|first1=M.|title=Tim Noakes and the peculiar hearing that didn’t happen|url=http://www.biznews.com/low-carb-healthy-fat-science/2015/06/05/tim-noakes-and-the-peculiar-hearing-that-didnt-happen/|accessdate=19 February 2016|agency=BizNews.com|date=5 June 2015|ref=Sboros_Tim Noakes and the peculiar hearing that didn’t happen}} The first session of the hearing took place from 23 to 30 November 2015, after which proceedings were postponed to February 2016. The second session resumed on 8 February{{cite news|last1=Sboros|first1=M.|title=Tim Noakes trial: the best to hope for – madness or miracle?|url=http://www.biznews.com/low-carb-healthy-fat-science/2016/02/08/tim-noakes-banting-babies-trial-best-outcome-hope/|accessdate=19 February 2016|agency=BizNews.com|date=8 February 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Sboros|first1=M.|title=Tim Noakes ‘trial’: did HPCSA set him up in a cat ‘n mouse game?|url=http://www.biznews.com/low-carb-healthy-fat-science/2016/02/09/tim-noakes-trial-did-hpcsa-set-him-up-in-nasty-game-lchf-banting/|accessdate=19 February 2016|agency=BizNews.com|date=9 February 2016}} and ended on 16 February 2016.{{cite news|last1=Sboros|first1=M.|title=Tim Noakes: caught in a turf war over an inconvenient truth?|url=https://www.biznews.com/low-carb-healthy-fat-science/2016/02/22/tim-noakes-is-he-caught-up-in-a-turf-war-over-inconvenient-truth-banting-lchf/|accessdate=22 February 2016|agency=BizNews.com|date=22 February 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Sboros|first1=M.|title=Tim Noakes: seeing into the future of food as medicine|url=https://www.biznews.com/low-carb-healthy-fat-science/2016/02/23/tim-noakes-seeing-into-future-food-medicine-banting-lchf/|accessdate=23 February 2016|publisher=BizNews.com|date=23 February 2016}} The hearing resumed on 17 October 2016. Controversially, on 28 October, the HPSCA mistakenly released a statement announcing that Noakes had been found guilty of misconduct. In a second press release issued over three hours later, the HPSCA apologized for the mistake.{{Cite news|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2016-10-28-tim-noakes-not-guilty-of-unprofessional-conduct-matter-adjourned-until-april-2017/|title=No ruling from Tim Noakes hearing, matter adjourned until April 2017|last=Etheridge|first=Jenna|work=The M&G Online|access-date=25 April 2017|language=en}} The hearing was again postponed until April 2017. Noakes was cleared of misconduct on 21 April 2017.{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/local/2017/04/21/Tim-Noakes-cleared-of-misconduct-over-%E2%80%98baby-Banting%E2%80%99-tweet|title=Tim Noakes cleared of misconduct over ‘baby Banting’ tweet|last=Digital|first=TMG|website=Times LIVE|access-date=25 April 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.medicalbrief.co.za/archives/oakes-cleared-misconduct-full-hpcsa-judgment/|title=Noakes cleared of misconduct. Full HPCSA judgment|website= Medical Brief|access-date=5 May 2017|date=26 April 2017}} The HPSCA filed an appeal on 2nd day of August 2017. http://foodmed.net/2017/appeal.pdf 8 June 2018 the appeal was dismissed in a unanimous ruling.http://foodmed.net/2018/06/noakes-free-hpcsa-licks-wounds-lchf/ ==Awards and Achievements== Noakes has challenged some common and old paradigms in the discipline of [[exercise physiology]].{{citation needed|date=November 2010}} In 1996 he was honored by the [[American College of Sports Medicine]] when he was asked to present the J.B. Wolfe Memorial Lecture, the college's keynote address at its annual meeting. In 2002 he was awarded a Doctorate in Science (DSc). In 2002 Noakes was awarded the International Cannes Grand Prix Award for Research in Medicine and Water, for his work on [[Exercise-associated hyponatremia|Exercise-associated Hyponatremia (EAH)]]. In 2004 Runner’s World (USA) included this work as one of the 40 most important “persons or events” in the sport of running in the past 40 years. In 2008 he was elected an honorary fellow of the Faculty of Sports and Exercise Medicine (UK), the first foreigner to be so recognised. In that year he also received the [[Order of Mapungubwe|Order of Mapungubwe (Silver)]], from the President of South Africa for his “excellent contribution in the field of sports and the science of physical exercise”. In 2011 Noakes was awarded an honorary doctorate by the [[Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam|Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, Netherlands]].{{cite web|title=Honorary doctorates|url=https://www.vu.nl/en/research/topresearchers-at-vu/honorary-doctorates/index.aspx|website=VU University: Research|publisher=Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam|accessdate=23 February 2016}} In 2012 he received the Lifetime Achievement Award from [[National Research Foundation of South Africa|South Africa's National Research Foundation]] for his contribution to sports science research. In 2014 the [[Southern Africa Association for the Advancement of Science|Southern Africa Association for the Advancement of Science (S2A3)]] awarded Noakes their prestigious South Africa Medal (gold) for his outstanding contributions to sport physiology.Plug, C. (2015). [http://s2a3.org.za/joomla/files/archives/2015_Marloth_Brochure.pdf "The 2014 South Africa Medal (gold): Awarded to Professor Timothy Noakes"], ''Rudolf Marloth Brochure'' 2015: 1–3. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Order of Mapungubwe|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Noakes, Timothy}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Alumni of Diocesan College, Cape Town]] [[Category:Exercise physiologists]] [[Category:Diet food advocates]] [[Category:High-fat diet advocates]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sports scientists]] [[Category:University of Cape Town academics]] [[Category:University of Cape Town alumni]]

Capacity: 2,500 | ballpark = | stadium = | city = [[Dubrovnik]], [[Croatia]] | colours = {{Color box|red|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|blue|border=darkgray}} | owner = | president = Tomislav Dumančić | coach = [[Vjekoslav Kobešćak]] | manager = | championships = | titles = | cheerleaders = | dancers = | mascot = | broadcasters = | media = | website = [http://www.jug.hr/ jug.hr] }} '''Vaterpolski klub Jug ''' ({{lang-en|Jug Water Polo Club}}) is a [[Croatia]]n [[water polo]] club from [[Dubrovnik]]. Currently, VK Jug competes in the [[Croatian First League of Water Polo]] and in the [[Adriatic Water Polo League]]. The club was established in 1923 as part of sports society "JUG". ==Honours== *'''[[Croatian First League of Water Polo|National Championship of Croatia]]:''' 14 **2000, 2001, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2016, 2017, 2018 *'''[[Croatian Water Polo Cup|National Cup of Croatia]]:''' 13 **1994, 1996, 2000, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2016, 2017, 2018 *'''[[SFR Yugoslavia Water Polo Championship|National Championship of SFR Yugoslavia]]:''' 8 **1949, 1950, 1951, 1980, 1981, 1982, 1983, 1985 *'''National Cup of Communist Yugoslavia:''' 2 **1981, 1983 *'''[[Kingdom of Yugoslavia Water Polo Championship|National Championship of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia]]:''' 14 **1925, 1926, 1927, 1928, 1929, 1930, 1931, 1932, 1933, 1934, 1935, 1936, 1937, 1940 *'''[[LEN Euroleague|LEN Champions League]]:''' 4 **1981, [[2000–01 LEN Champions League|2001]], [[2005–06 LEN Euroleague|2006]], [[2015–16 LEN Champions League|2016]] *'''[[LEN Super Cup]]:''' 2 **2006, 2016 *'''[[LEN Cup]]:''' 1 **2000 *'''[[Adriatic Water Polo League]]:''' 4 **2009, 2016, 2017, 2018 ==Notable players== *[[Vladimir Ivković]] *[[Hrvoje Kačić]] *[[Božo Vuletić]] *[[Veselin Đuho]] *[[Goran Sukno]] *[[Ognjen Kržić]] *[[Maro Balić]] *[[Miho Bošković]] *[[Sandro Sukno]] *[[Tamás Molnár]] *[[Tony Azevedo]] *[[Mile Smodlaka]] *[[Maro Joković]] *[[Andro Bušlje]] *[[Frano Vićan]] *[[Ryan Bailey (water polo)|Ryan Bailey]] *[[Felipe Perrone]] ==Notable coaches== *[[Veselin Đuho]] *[[Elvis Fatović]] *[[Emil Nikolić]] *[[Vjekoslav Kobešćak]] *[[Vladimir Ivković]] *[[Milivoj Petković]] *[[Ivo Trumbić]] *[[Trifko Banđur]] ==External links== *[http://www.jug.hr/ Official website] {{hr icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jug, VK}} [[Category:Sports clubs established in 1923]] [[Category:Water polo clubs in Croatia]] [[Category:LEN Euroleague clubs]] [[Category:Sport in Dubrovnik]] {{Croatia-sport-stub}} {{waterpolo-team-stub}}

{{Convert|110|x|72|m|abbr=on}} |construction_cost = |architect = |former_names = Spartak Stadium |tenants = [[FC Zhetysu]] |seating_capacity = 4,000 }} '''Zhetysu Stadium''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Taldykorgan]], [[Kazakhstan]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and hosts the home matches of [[FC Zhetysu]]. {{coord|45.019716|78.365103|display=title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:4000}} ==External links== *[http://www.fc-zhetisu.kz/?id=stadion Page from club website] {{ru icon}} {{Kazakhstan-sports-venue-stub}} [[Category:Football venues in Kazakhstan]]
